reviews.review_title: Isle of Dogs - Leads You On A Curious Journey
reviews.content: Anyone who likes a different kind of storytelling should find something to appreciate in this offbeat, but winning movie. Regardless of being a stop motion 'fairytale' (?) there's enough gritty realism and unexpected themes explored to make this quite compelling indeed! Others, I feel have looked too deeply into the political and racial aspects of the, at times, rather emotional situations covered by writer/director Wes Anderson (even though there are certainly many astute observations to be considered). Alexandre Desplat's excellent and highly inventive music score adds much mood and movement to overall proceedings. While I expect, "Isle of "Dogs" won't be everyone's choice of entertainment it will please and intrigue more than it may alienate.I had not read anything about this movie before watching and was convinced it was a Japanese production - only to be surprised at the finish to find it was mostly American. Highly recommended for a somewhat sardonic, dark and insightful journey into imagination and would expect it should garnish some attention at this year's Global Awards. The visuals by British cinematographer Tristan Oliver are standout.While not many may remember a British animated film by Richard Williams from '58 titled: "The Little Island" much of the humorous visual style of "Dogs" bears a resemblance, and makes this rare featurette worth seeking out - simultaneously very funny and serious.

In the fictional Megasaki City in Japan, all dogs have been exiled to Trash Island due to reports of a canine flu virus. A young boy travels to the island to try to find his pet dog. In the meantime, various conflicts and alliances occur on both the city and the island. "Isle of Dogs" is a stop-motion animated film and is mostly in the English language with some Japanese. It is a U.S./German co-production.Like "Fantastic Mr. Fox", director Wes Anderson has led a creative team (including an all-star cast) that is accompanied by very clever and enjoyable animation. The story is also well structured with interesting twists and surprises even though the eventual climax - and its build-up - seem to lack clarity and excitement at times.But it stands out mainly due to its characters especially the dog Chief, voiced by Bryan Cranston. As the occasionally self-appointed leader of a gang of five male dogs, Chief stands out as he is a stray dog compared to his peers whose previous life circumstances were relatively privileged. His outsider perspective and attitude provide many of the movie's greatest insights.

reviews.review_title: I don't get the good reviews
reviews.content: Oh my god it was boring! Where did all these people who gave it 8, 9 or 10 stars come from? I almost fell asleep in it! The story moved so slowly, was uninteresting and completely predictable. I thought it was going to be a cute film about dogs, it wasn't. NOT RECOMMENDED!!!

reviews.review_title: Full of Wes Anderson's charming cinematography but not too much else.
reviews.content: A few years ago, I got on a Wes Anderson kick. I practically watched his entire filmography to that point in one long binge-worthy day. After catching up, I felt I truly appreciated his quirky, orthogonal cinematography and deeply complex characters. I've essentially been a fan of his since Moonrise Kingdom (2012), so I was looking forward to his latest work, Isle of Dogs(2018). After all, he had proven his skill at stop-motion animation with The Fantastic Mr. Fox (2009) and had received nominations for Best Picture and Best Director for The Grand Budapest Hotel (2014) since then.Unfortunately, while Isle of Dogs carries Anderson's distinct style and charm, it felt a little watered down. Sure, the shots were full of their beauty and symmetry, and the story had its cute moments, but it mostly felt like he was on autopilot. Maybe the PG-13 rating was holding him back? I don't know. In most fiction, there is a suspension of disbelief, but setting this film 20 years in the future while still holding to the aesthetic of the antique (I doubt there will be nearly that many reel-to-reels in the future) seemed to backfire a little.I'll give Wes Anderson some credit, though: he did try something new by including the "language barrier" and adopting the Japanese style as much as he could. It also seems that stop-motion techniques have improved significantly since The Fantastic Mr. Fox, likely due to many of the same 3-D printing technologies used for Kubo and the Two Strings (2016). The mixture of 3-D stop-motion and 2-D animation in Isle of Dogs should also be commended. In the end, I think my main qualm with this film was that it was a smidge too predictable. Perhaps this was due to the standard McGuffin of the boy trying to be reunited with his dog.Full of Wes Anderson's charming cinematography but not too much else, I give Isle of Dogs 3.5 stars out of 5.

Another masterpiece directed by Wes Anderson.
Difficult to find some defaults, everything flow without smudging till the end. Wicked!

Whether he knows it or not, Wes Anderson is an animator trapped in a filmmaker's body. Like Tim Burton, he's a visionary director with a peculiar, oddball style of telling stories. But when he gets into the realm of stop-motion animation, there is no limit to where his imagination takes him. Isle of Dogs is one of the most spectacularly beautiful pieces of animation in a very long time. As to where this falls in Anderson's filmography, I'd put it near the top and quite a few spots above The Grand Budapest Hotel, a film that's perceived to be his masterpiece. It wasn't, but this one just might be it.From the opening shot, I couldn't take my eyes off of the screen. I let go of every perceivable reservation and let Anderson's entire universe overtake me. What a universe it is.Somewhere in the not so distant future, a Japanese city called Megasaki is run by cynophobic, cat supremacist, fascist, Mayor Kobayashi. He institutes extreme measures of quarantine and expulsion of dogs from his city after a curious case of dog flu threatens his citizens. The dogs, now stranded on Trash Island, forage and try to stay alive yet seem to communicate like self-aware entities in an old Woody Allen comedy. The five dogs we meet are voiced by Anderson favorites (Norton, Murray, Goldblum, Balaban) with the exception of Bryan Cranston, who plays the feral stray dog leader, Chief. The designs of these dogs all have something to gaze in wonder at. For example Boss (Murray) has dark button eyes and wears an adorable sweater as the former mascot of a local junior baseball team. Another dog we see later in the film named Jupiter, played by F. Murray Abraham, sports a canteen of "turpentine brandy" around his neck. All are furry and all are downright cuddly. Torpedoing from Megasaki is a stowaway child pilot named Atari Kobayashi, on a mission to rescue his beloved dog Spots (Liev Schrieber) from Trash Island. Meanwhile, an underground resistance of the Mayor and his iron fisted rule is growing in Megasaki. Leading it is an American foreign exchange student, Tracy, played by Greta Gerwig. I could only describe her as a cross between Norma Rae and Little Orphan Annie. She uncovers a conspiracy which proves indefinitely that the epidemic of dog flu was invented by the government in order to eradicate Dogs as a species, Nazi style.With an engaging plot like that and such richly constructed environments and characters such as these, nearly everything should go right and it does. It's 100 minutes of bliss. It never deviates from Wes Anderson's signature narrative style which at times has proven to be grating in live-acting. But in the world of stop-motion animation, it's enchanting and it fits him like a glove. I found myself to be the only person laughing out-loud in the theater, not because the movie is deliberately trying to make me laugh, but out of sheer joy at the amount of fun Anderson had in making this. But we had to wait 10 years to see him dare to venture into this world again. Here is a word of advice. Wes, animation is your greatest strength. Keep doing it.

reviews.review_title: Isle of Dogs is basically what would happen if Wes Anderson made a Studio Ghibli film. It's amazing
reviews.content: Wes Anderson has one of the most unique styles of modern cinema. His combination of specific color patterns, off kilter soundtracks, comedy, consistent still camera angles, and occasional reoccurring actors like Bill Murray and Edward Norton gives him the rare distinction of having movies that really don't resemble someone else's. I think that a lot of it comes from how even with a large cast, his movies manage to feel like small, unimportant independent movies...even though their still filled with passion. Wes Anderson has shown that he's not afraid to try out other genres ; his most prominent example being that of Fantastic Mr. Fox in 2009. Fantastic Mr. Fox was his chance to not only do something more family friendly, but was his first (and as of 2018, his only) adaptation of another story. But unlike other animation styles of Disney and DreamWorks, Fantastic Mr. Fox embraced it's identity by combining stop motion that looked intentionally unclean, but still kept a lot of the typical Wes Anderson traits. The movie came out great and I'd had always wanted him to do another animated movie. Not only is Isle of Dogs another stop motion story, but one that's also original. Set in the near future in Megasaki City, Japan, an outbreak of dog flu is spreading amongst the canine population. Mayor Kobayashi decrees that all dogs are to be quarantined to a nearby trash island until a cure is found. Six months later, the dogs have formed a variety of tribes and packs, with the only goal of surviving. In one group, we have the leader Chief (played by Brian Cranston), Rex (played by Edward Norton), King (played by Bob Balban), Duke (played by Jeff Goldblum), and Boss (played by Bill Murray). All except for Chief had lives of families, celebrity, and comfort. Chief was merely a stray that became leader. About six months after the decree, a boy Atari Kobayashi crash lands his plane on the island, looking for his bodyguard dog Spots (played by Live Schreiber). Though the dogs can't understand his Japanese, they understand what he's looking for and agree to try and find him. Meanwhile, back on land, there is a conspiracy that the mayor doesn't want a cure found and would rather exterminate the dogs. Transfer student Tracy Walker (played by Greta Gerwig) tries to get some answers for her school newspaper. I'm happy to say that not only is Isle of Dogs a great movie, but it's an improvement on Fantastic Mr. Fox. Even though I like that movie as well, the latter film suffers from a story that seems to be focused on trying to be a crowd pleaser. Isle of Dogs doesn't talk down to people. In fact, I'd say the movie is a combination Japanese samurai, political thriller, and a little bit of a Woody Allen comedy. And yet it all still feels like it fits into Wes Anderson's style. The animation, which is clearly representing something like Raken-Bass, keeps a lot of the roughness featured in Fantastic Mr. Fox. Though you can tell that some things were touched up by computers, this is an example of good C.G.I, when it's merely used to remove strings. It's never overpowering and it maintains the "unclean" look that's still intentional. Each of the dogs look different and make it easy to tell who is who. There are even similar breeds that stand out thanks to the voice acting.Let's talk about the voice-overs. Wes Anderson is an actors director, who knows how to take advantage of each persons skills. He gets a quality mix of Brian Cranston's eccentrics and stern demeanor. This develops into a character that's troubled, but someone who could still be redeemed. Though we certainly get plenty of time with the other animals, Brian Cranston's character gets the most focus and rightfully so. What about the humans? Wes Anderson made the interesting decision to keep the majority of human cast speaking Japanese. A lot of it isn't even translated and were simply supposed to figure out what their feeling or tying to get across. This will definitely stress some audience people that want something more straightforward, though this creates more of a visual experience. I'd compare Isle of Dogs a lot like a silent movie with dialogue. I'll give this ten robot dogs out of ten. Isle of Dogs is more proof on why Wes Anderson is one of my favorite directors. He's an artist whose not afraid to keep evolving his work to create something that's all his own. It's hard to imagine Disney or even Pixar making a story like this. It's heart felled, funny, interesting, and impressive. Go see this and then give our dog a hug.

Wes Anderson is quite the unique filmmaker who is well known for his distinct visual and narrative style, as well as his offbeat sense of humor. When he entered in the realm of animation, he delivered his lovable sensibilities and tropes into a stop-motion film adaptation of Roald Dahl's Fantastic Mr. Fox. So when it was announced that he was making another stop-motion animated feature, and his own original creation at that, it was a guarantee that Isle of Dogs would be a unique take on the talking dog movie, complete with huge admiration for the animal. Right off the bat, the animation is truly astounding from start to finish. Every frame has at least some attention to detail, complete with the fur moving as the characters move, water coming from the eyes, background sets and lights, aircraft, Japanese cultural architecture and art, and so much more. The designs of the characters look relatively simplistic but still look aggressive, rough and full of life, and their movements are well defined and energized, even when they're static. The way the animators were able to make the dogs talk is admirable enough, but the way they move as well is quite accurate given the limitations of real life dog movements. I'd say the opening does a great job bringing the audience into the experience, with Anderson's trademark framing establishing a great contrast between the fully lit Megasaki City and the heinous trash ridden island for dogs, and kudos to the small bits of hand-drawn animation done when the televisions are on.The general story itself centers around a young boy named Atari Kobayashi who goes in search of his dog Spots after all of the dogs in Japan are banished to an island from an illness outbreak. Along with a group of dogs who will do anything to not only help him but to also get off the island, the boy sets off on his quest to find his dog while the flu dilemma tries to be solved. If the visuals make one's eyes gouge, then the unpredictable outcomes of the story suck one in, as it's hard to figure out what will happen next, complete with flashbacks that unleash numerous upon numerous of layers nobody will see coming. There are several subplots that run afloat, such as a pro-dog activist group led by the stern foreign exchange student Tracy Walker, yet none feel out of place and are genuinely well woven together. In fact, when stakes and bloodshed do arise between the humans and dogs, one might reimagine the dark talking animal pictures Watership Down and The Plague Dogs, complete with the rough atmosphere and affection towards the animals themselves. From the heart, Isle of Dogs is truthfully about the bond between people and man's best friend, and when the dogs do interact with the good hearted people, it's hard not to just want to adopt a dog of your own those moments are so heartwarming.In addition, the humor is the usual deadpan dialogue common in Anderson's films, which help fit the cast. With a mix of Anderson's usual actors such as Bill Murray, Edward Norton, Bryan Cranston, Jeff Goldblum, Scarlett Johansson and more for the dogs, and a Japanese cast for most of the humans, they all bring their own distinctive voices for the characters they play without overpowering them. While the dogs are humorous enough, the one dog given the most development in the film is Chief, as his relation with Atari helps bring the raw emotions and heart the film displays in its love for dogs. On another added note, considering that most of the humans are Japanese, Anderson cleverly chooses not to use subtitles when they speak. You know you're fantastic at storytelling when even those who don't speak the Japanese language will still understand what is going on, treating the viewers with respect and sincerity.Over the years, we've seen live-action filmmakers experiment with the art of animation, and Isle of Dogs definitely stands as one of the best examples of succeeding in such a task. With a suspenseful and captivating story, phenomenally crafted animation, a great cast of characters worth rooting for and genuine love and respect for Japanese culture, Wes Anderson has showcased his love for the unlimited possibilities that the medium of animation can accomplish through visual storytelling. Using stop-motion requires the upmost patience and attention to perfect, making the final product all the more admirable. If you're a fan of Wes Anderson, animation, or dogs in general, seek this one out and give it your full love and attention, like any dog. Here's to more great animated features Wes Anderson hopefully makes in the future, and to more great animated films yet to come this year.
When will I learn when there's an all star cast and rave reviews means it's absolute crap, which this film is.

Isle of Dogs, from its first frame, oozes style. The amount of craft shown in this film is incredible, but even then, they still manage to tell an emotionally involved story.The film is set in Japan, but not in the real sense. 20 years into a dystopian future of a strange mix of different states of culture and technology. This strange and wonderful setting elevates the film in ways that weren't even necessary. You could have essentially told the same story set in the United States, or anywhere else for that matter, but instead they decided to put it in Japan, which gave them a tremendous amount of creative freedom to tell a story that is entirely unique in presentation.Some critics have complained about cultural appropriation, asking whether or not the representation of Japan in this film is fair or sensitive. I'm not Japanese, so I cannot answer for them, but I would hope these people would ask the number of Japanese people who worked on this film, from story to acting, and I'm sure they would have perfectly valid answers for the creative decisions made. This version of 'Japan' isn't meant to be real, it's meant to be a fantasy world inspired by Japan, a world where such a ridiculous story could occur. We don't hear people complaining about cultural appropriation and sensitivity in regards to Avatar: The Last Airbender, so they shouldn't be here.Now a decent criticism you could levy at this film is the severe lack of well developed female characters. There are five female characters with speaking roles. One is an interpreter, one is Yoko Ono, and the other three serve as romantic partners for the three major characters (Chief, Spots and Atari), and not very well developed ones at that. I'm not going to dock a star for this because I rate movies based on how much I enjoyed the experience, not based on any nitpicks or technical issues, but as a person who does care about positive and progressive representation of women and minorities, it is disappointing that the only real inclusion of female characters in this film were to fill in shallow, one dimensional romances in a story that didn't need them.That shouldn't affect your ability to come into this film and enjoy it though. This is an incredible film with a lot of value. The art design, direction and story are strong, funny and at times dark. This is an incredibly unique film that deserves all the money it can get.

Short and Simple Review by WubsTheFadgerWes Anderson had made some of my favorite films including: Fantastic Mr. 
Fox and The Grand Budapest Hotel. Wes Anderson's Isle of Dogs is another fantastic film that is original, creative, and funny. The story is fluid and has a lot of humor throughout. The emotional parts are genuine and the theme of the film is very good. The visuals and stop motion are beautiful. The story is whimsical and a great piece of fiction.The voice acting is very good. Bryan Cranston, Edward Norton, Koyu Rankin, Bob Balaban, Bill Murray, Jeff Goldblum, and many others perform very well. Jeff Goldblum's Duke is hilarious and Bryan Cranston's voice acting is perfect.The pacing is great and the film flows smoothly. The runtime is a little overlong.This film is not a masterpiece, but I do believe it deserves a good score because it is so beautiful to look and an because of originality.Pros: Great, whimsical, and funny story, great characters, amazing voice acting, Jeff Goldblum and Bryan Cranston's performance, good pacing, and a lot of good humorCons: The runtime is a bit overlongOverall Rating: 8.7

This movie didn't give me one ounce of boredom throughout the entire thing. I was on the edge of my seat at every twist and, and when I was done I started craving more. Overall great film to take your friends and even your kids too. Ignore the PG-13 it's great for kids to go see.
This movie was sweet and simple and beautifully directed by Wes. The animation was also beautiful and so was the story. Overall, a great watch. You will surely love it.

Maybe the frame of story is a bit too large, compared to the first half of film that is perfect; the ending of this film is relatively modest. In this case, of course, Wes Anderson, the director, quickly remedied the film with his own aesthetic, and added Japanese elements masterly in his personal style. Once again, the strong emotional expression and the serious metaphor in story are amazingly reflected in a infantile but deliberate way, like what he has perfectly done in Fantastic Mr. Fox. However, the unexplainable pain that runs through his previous works has been repressed and replaced with a benevolent understanding.

reviews.review_title: I should be predisposed to love this.
reviews.content: The ever quirky and inventive Wes Anderson directing an animation, what's not to fall madly in love with. Yes it's got more stars in the voiceover cast than a whole summers worth of blockbusters. Yes it's effortlessly beautiful, gorgeous, exceptionally so. Yes it's brimming with dark humour, but most importantly it knows how to have fun. The dialogue though. Fast, witty, sharp, one line rolling over another with breakneck dexterity. The story is simple, delightful even. Boy seeks lost dog, on an island of dogs, that talk, live amongst garbage and oh some robodogs, from the municipal task force on the mainland that's looking for the boy, as are the slightly militant activists, that support the K9 uprising, see, simple! It's very entertaining and well worth a watch, however it's not quite Anderson at his very best.

reviews.review_title: Yet another quirky look into the mindset of Wes Anderson and further proves his versatility as a filmmaker
reviews.content: Isle of Dogs is a stop-motion animated film co-written and directed by Wes Anderson (Fantastic Mr. Fox, The Grand Budapest Hotel). Featuring the voices of Bryan Cranston, Edward Norton, and Bill Murray, it is yet another quirky look into the mindset of the acclaimed director and further proves his versatility as a filmmaker.In a futuristic Japan, a serious virus spreads throughout its dog population and as a result, all dogs are banished to an isolated place called "Trash Island". One day, a young boy named Atari sets off to Trash Island to search for his dog Spots, who was the first dog to be sent there during the banishment.Despite its cute presentation, Isle of Dogs is not a kid's film. Some of its dark themes and plot elements would likely be too complex and intense for most children under the age of ten, but anyone older should find plenty to enjoy. The voice acting is terrific, especially from Bryan Cranston as the stray dog Chief, who is responsible for a great deal of the film's dry humour. At times, however, the pacing feels off due to some strangely inserted flashback scenes. In addition to this, the lack of subtitles during some Japanese dialogue can be frustrating to anyone who doesn't understand the language, as an interpreter's translation becomes quite distracting when trying to understand the story. Director Wes Anderson's trademarks are once again on full display; his use of symmetrical framing, his unique use of colour, his interesting oddball characters, truly one of the most artistic filmmakers right now. One can only hope he continues making stop-motion animation films like this and Fantastic Mr. Fox.I rate it 8/10

reviews.review_title: A scrappy, meticulously crafted animation from Anderson.
reviews.content: Stop motion animation is a painstakingly long process. In Laika's fourth feature, Kubo and the Two Strings (2016), a 16-foot skeleton was constructed over a 6 month period and took an entire year to film its sequence, resulting in 49.2 seconds worth of footage in the completed film. With facts like these, it's evident that stop motion films are true labours of love, involving countless animators to bring these visions to life. Wes Anderson's second foray into stop motion cinema (his first being 2009's Fantastic Mr. Fox) is Isle of Dogs, set in Japan and boasting a large, impressive cast list. With fears of an outbreak of snout fever becoming overwhelming throughout Japan, Kobayashi, the Mayor of Megasaki City, banishes all dogs to an island of trash, ensuring the citizens that a cure is impossible. First on the list is Spots (Liev Schieber) the beloved dog of Atari Kobayashi (Koyu Rankin), ward of Mayor Kobayashi. Several months pass, and Atari flies out to trash island in search of Spots, and is immediately joined on his quest by a ragtag group of dogs, including Rex (Norton), King (Bob Balaban), Duke (Jeff Goldblum), Boss (Murray), and Chief (Cranston). One of the most notable things about Isle of Dogs is the characteristics and expressions of the dogs. There is so much emotion and detail in their eyes, and the animation perfectly captures their mannerisms and provides the audience with a selection of lovable characters to spend time with on an island towering with garbage. Scrappy and rough, yet strangely beautiful, the films aesthetic is a certainly unique one. Anderson splits the film into two storylines that ultimately unite towards the end. The first features Atari and the dogs travelling across the island in search of Spots, and the second centring on Tracey Walker (Lady Birds writer/director Greta Gerwig) investigating a conspiracy surrounding Major Kobayashi. Whilst this secondary plot doesn't quite measure up to the strengths of Atari's quest, it still works and results in a satisfying conclusion to both arcs. One of the sweetest aspects of the film is the bond between Atari and stray dog Chief, who makes it clear on several occasions after Atari's unexpected arrival that he does not bow to any master, yet over the course of the film gradually eases up and becomes a loyal aid to his quest. A quirky, sweet tale of the bond between a boy and his dog, Anderson's second stop motion film is an enjoyable animated adventure that finds beauty in the unlikeliest of places.

Absolutely amazing: from the animation, of course (incredible stop-motion technique, I was completely blown away by the special ef-fur-ects) but also the wittiness, the voices, the story to he astute indictment against our obtuse societies.

reviews.review_title: Not Anderson's best...but that is a high bar
reviews.content: If you are a junkie for the Wes Anderson aesthetic (I am), this movie is well worth your time. From the large cast of quirky characters to the understated emotion/ comedy to the constant attention to detail, it checks every single box. It is beautiful and charming and whimsical. Is it actually entertaining? Well, that's a trickier question. Aesthetic alone isn't really enough, after all. You should have some genuine tension or suspense or concern for the characters. I never quite got there. As a result, this was not my favorite Anderson joint. Then again, that's a high bar, and I got my fix.

Wes Anderson does it again. This could be one of the best animated films that came out in 2018.First off, it's a beautiful film. Hands down. Wes Anderson works his magic and showcases his skill at set-building in every single scene. The choice of stop-motion allows Anderson an insane amount of detail. From individual hairs to random fleas that scurry, no piece of detail gets left out. Each scene is beautiful and stands out on their own. Colors and visuals and media styles mix and blend together to create a beautiful film. The animation is nothing less than captivating.But the film is more than a delight to the eyes, it's a delight to the ears as well. The music and sounds were perfect. Loved the music throughout. The voice cast was well selected. It's fun guessing which person is playing which character.The plot was unique and heartwarming. Who can't like a story about a boy and his dog? There are some suspenseful moments, it's a feel-good movie throughout.I enjoyed the nod to Japanese culture and Anderson's choice of not having subtitles. Though confusing at first, it increases the level of immersion. Double points for accurate Japanese. That's one area most American filmmakers neglect.I don't think any animated 2018 film could have topped this.5/5. I loved it. Sorry, cat-lovers.

reviews.review_title: Gave it half hour, what a waste
reviews.content: I'm a fan of Anderson, watched all of his movies, but this one is a mess. After half hour still not going anywhere narratively. Thumbs up for the animation, but really you can't just survive on Anderson jokes and clichés on social segregation.

Wes Anderson has outdone himself, with this incredible film. So creative. If you are a fan, YOU CANNOT MISS THIS FILM.
The animation is superb! Watch multiple times, to catch the subtle nuisances.

reviews.review_title: Animation of a riveting simple story
reviews.content: This review contains spoilers.Isle of Dogs is an animated movie directed by Wes Anderson. The movie features an ensemble cast portraying humans and dogs. The movie follows a boy named Atari as he aims to find his bodyguard dog that has been exiled to trash island following an epidemic. On the island, the boy finds a group of dogs that help him locate his lost dog.Isle of Dogs is a gorgeous movie to look at. Although the animation may be basic, the movie does a good job with the visuals. Every dog, smoke, human, and background look distinct. The voice acting is also impressive with the ensemble cast chiming in and delivering lines with emotion. This mix of clean and distinct auditory and visual experiences makes the movie engrossing to follow.The story is incredibly basic. From the beginning of the movie, the story is already told and it plays out mostly in the same way. The movie contains too many characters that distracts from its main story. One of these is the foreign exchange student, Tracy. I enjoyed her character but much of her story took time away from Atari and the dogs on trash island. The movie uses a lot of flashbacks and side stories. All of this is fine to anyone who enjoys Wes Anderson but to anyone viewing his movies for the first time, they may be taken off guard.Overall, Isle of Dogs is a recommended movie. It features many common styles from Wes Anderson and is one of his more approachable movies.Grade: B
This animated film feels geared as much at adults as a younger audience. It's dark and different and entertaining. The animation also has a very different "look" to it that I loved.

My dog seemed to be paying attention. I don't know if he was following the story.The animation is different and it appears to have been made for Dogs.It has a nice characters. The plot is Dogs are causing flu in Japan and have been exiled to an Island.When the mayors nephews bodyguard Dog is sent there. The boy, Atari sets out to find him and rescue him.An A star voicing cast.It still has a Wes Anderson feel to it.6oo words need to be obtained so CTRL C, CTRL V coming up, sorryMy dog seemed to be paying attention. I don't know if he was following the story.The animation is different and it appears to have been made for Dogs.It has a nice characters. The plot is Dogs are causing flu in Japan and have been exiled to an Island.When the mayors nephews bodyguard Dog is sent there. The boy, Atari sets out to find him and rescue him.
Beautiful, thoughtful, magical Film, full of character.

Isle of Dogs review:Isle of Dogs is Wes Anderson's latest film. In Japan, there is an abundance of dogs and they're all getting sick with various diseases. Their solution to the problem is to send all dogs to Trash Island where they can scavenge for themselves. A little boy from Japan named Atari, the mayor's son, flies over to the island to look for his dog, Spots, and a group of dogs journey in help to find him. So this movie had a limited release I think about a month ago. It was given a lot of praise and buzz so last week there was a little bit of a wider release. This week it finally got a wide release. This movie was great! Unique and original. All of the voice actor were amazing. It's almost like the characters they had were a reflection of themselves. The stand out for me were Bill Murray, Jeff Goldblum, Edward Norton, Bryan Cranston, and finally Koyu Rankin as Atari. I like Wes Anderson's idea for stop motion. This is his second stop motion movie, Fantastic Mr. Fox being his first. Alexandre Desplat creates a great score, like he always does. The only flaws I had were that there was a side plot with one character that wasn't necessary, but I still liked it. Some scenes dragged on just a little too. Other than that I thought Isle of Dogs was a great movie and people should go see it, as our theatre only sold 5 tickets altogether last night.
My Grade: A-

reviews.review_title: Beautiful animation leads another feel-good, simple Wes Anderson movie
reviews.content: Just like Fantastic Mr. Fox, Isle of Dogs is a pleasant, easy to watch movie with an unremarkable plot. The premise was an interesting one, and the characters were original and fun. The excellent stop- motion animation was the best thing about the movie. The plot was a little thin, and several leaps (the sudden, easy political downfall of Kobayashi and the effect a couple kids had on the process, especially the hacker, seemed unrealistic), but I think with movies like this, you can't get bogged down in that and have to just appreciate the positive, fun movie presented. Like my previous Wes Anderson movies, I think of them as easy, happy, but not especially deep or thought provoking films.

As someone who had never(never) seen a Wes Anderson film, I was captivated. To me this film felt truly extraordinary. The story was well made, thought out and has metaphors still relevant in society. It felt original and not something that could have just been conjured up. Its stop motion animation makes you question whether it even was animated. Along with that, it uses fantastically made 2D animation to further advance the story. The music and score in this film set tones of anger, grief and hope the characters are feeling.Watching it for a second time allows you to notice the subtleties it contains. Inside of the film is references to previous works of art. Backgrounds of the characters suddenly become more significant and meaningful. The voice actors each embody their respective characters perfectly.For me its the best animated film I have seen in a while. Everything about it from the start to the finish was thought out perfectly. Even the things we may never even notice.

reviews.review_title: A movie about dogs - good, a Wes Anderson movie about dogs - better!
reviews.content: Everything is there what you'd expect from a Wes Anderson movie: a bit odd premise, dry humor and that bittersweet melancholy feeling throughout. The animation is superb and the all-star cast is great. Story and characters are interesting, funny and more complex than you'd think. If you have liked anything by Wes Anderson before or are new to him, but interested in this, then there is no reason to miss it!

reviews.review_title: Ugh, how do you mess up a story about dogs?
reviews.content:
I adore Wes Anderson's films, yet I will admit Fantastic Mr Fox is perhaps my least favorite; something doesn't translate to animation for me. I was expecting to be transported or at least pleasantly entertained but a lot of the film irked me and thinking about it more afterward it bugged me even more. This is a beautifully animated movie and the visuals are pleasing as punch. However, the story seems to mean nothing and the characters are all flat.
 
Here are some of my random complaints:1. The concept of having one of the main characters only speak in Japanese with no translation felt distancing and we only see one short scene of him bonding with his dog he supposedly loves enough to risk everything for.2. Women are an afterthought in this movie. They exist only as a nearly silent assistant (the tragically underused Yoko Ono!), a sexualized trophy wife dog (Nutmeg played by ScarJo), a pregnant dog with no lines, an interpreter with only 1 line of her own dialogue. The only female character with any kind of agency is the white foreign exchange student who is A HIGH SCHOOL SENIOR WHO FALLS IN LOVE WITH 12 YEAR OLD BOY SHE HAS NEVER MET!3. The story is pretty brutal and realist about death, suffering and euthanasia and animal experiments but it told so flatly and matter of fact that it had no impact for me. Maybe I'm thankful they don't use the music and characters to really pull at your heartstrings since for the first half of the movie I was already questioning why I wanted to sit through a movie with so many dogs being tortured. Pretty bleak stuff. 4. The dialogue and characters have the Wes Anderson autistic flat affect where everything is delivered with the least amount of emotion as possible but taken to the extreme. This made me not really care about the kids or the dog.5. Deux Ex Machina to save the day at the end. The trials and tribulations of the main characters almost had no bearing on the resolution.6. Cats are given a pretty short end of the stick here. They are somehow benignly evil and there was something interesting to be uncovered there but the film just had them as background. I thought it was trying to avoid the cat vs dog cliche...but it didn't. The evil clan are the cat people.7. The had some real potential for dramatic adventure scenes but I never felt worried about the characters despite their head injuries, broken teeth, chewed off ears, missing limbs, etc. I'm usually a sucker for animals in danger but these characters all seemed to have the same personality. 8. I love Bill Murray, Jeff Goldblum and almost all the rest of the cast but they weren't allowed to really show off their voice acting talents. All the voices blended into one as the dogs were so dead pan. 9. And it did feel pretty white washed to have the cast be primarily white actors with the Japanese actors being untranslated. I wonder if in Japan they will subtitle or dub the dogs.In regards to the supposed political statements the film makes, they seem weak. Now he had set this in a more realistic version of say the Dog Meat Festivals in modern day China or had this be a story more closely analogous to refugees that would have been pretty bold.I can understand people enjoying this film but for me I just didn't understand what it was trying to say and it felt gimmicky and not like a Wes Anderson film. I read somewhere he directed the film in absentia, just emailing his notes for the animators and was pretty hands off for this film (unlike his auteurism on his other films).

reviews.review_title: Undeniably creative and fun. More eccentric but more streamlined than Fantastic Mr. Fox;
reviews.content:
The sort of plot from the getgo that you know will be a wild ride in which the themes and points will emerge. Cleverly and respectfully appropriating Japanese cinema and art makes for a uniquely beautiful film and one that renders the audience in the same camp as the dogs: unable to understand everything except for tone and a few choice words.
There's something special about hearing these legendary voices behind these hand animated creatures, and Wes Anderson has, in the dogs, created a sort of very refreshingly sweet, honest pack of fun characters for this adventure that intentionally don't fit the stereotypes you would associate with Alphas.
There's very little not to like about this movie except for the fact that it's very much of little consequence. But I can imagine rewatching this movie many times, sometimes for the visuals and sometimes for the pitch perfect acting/dialogue/animation.

2 minutes in switched to watch the BBC news better and more entertainment
nothing else to say about this

This is ravaging through the orient to repackage the loot and sell what hardly qualifies as a mid-day children's cartoon to us about the glib we want to believe is exotic AND meaningful, thrown out of proportion by an utterly unnecessary high-profile cast.

It's hard to think how a film could be more "Wes Anderson" than Isle of Dogs, a uniquely animated film set in a stereotypical fictional Japan. The story at its heart is simple, but it is told with Anderon's signature style turning it into an unforgettable romp.It's the animation style that really draws you into this. It's not to everyone's taste, and that's understandable. It's more grey than Anderson's normal work (unsurprising for a film set on a trash island) but Anderson is able to find colour in all that bleakness. The characters, mostly dogs, are charismatic and full of life. The environments are depicted in such a unique way that makes them feel colourful despite their greyness. Landscapes are brought to life in delightful 2D, Anderson playing with space in his eccentric way. And of course, there's symmetry, everywhere.There's been a lot of controversy about the depiction of Japan but the intention here is to use the setting to give the film a unique feeling, which it definitely does. Sure, the plot could work in any other country but Wes Anderson chose to set it in Japan and there's nothing wrong with playing on it in an animation clearly not set in the real world. All in all, the depiction of Japanese culture is respectful. One interesting quirk is that the Japanese isn't subtitled, yet it's always so easy to understand the dynamic of a scene. Then there's the way rooms and stickers are labelled in English in a way that really obviously tells you about their function. That would be totally out of place in any kind of film other than this, but here it successfully communicates things to the viewer while generating a few laughs along the way.The characters all have interesting personalities, exaggerated by the goofy animation. Chief, a former stray voiced by Bryan Cranston, goes through the most interesting change throughout the film and many other dogs have interesting personalities too, although the other four of Chief's pack seem to be pretty interchangeable. Human characters are depicted well, the main one being a 12-year-old boy who is a bit cold on the outside but has a good heart. Meanwhile the villains are depicted with hilarious exaggeration, with delightfully insane faces when carrying out their evil plans.The main plot isn't that deep. It could be read as political commentary, but whether it is or isn't, it isn't particularly deep. It's best when simply admired for its eccentricity. Dogs being deported to an island! A flu invented specifically to make people hate dogs more! A dog genocide plan! It's crazy in a self-aware way. In the end though, it isn't the plot that makes Isle of Dogs so entertaining, but the way it's told.

reviews.review_title: I love dogs, but this sucked
reviews.content: I am reading through reviews and have no idea how people think this movie was worth watching. Luckily I have movie pass so this pile of excrement didn't get my money, or I'd have asked for it back from the box office. The movie is tediously slow with below average imagery and poor writing. You know exactly how the movie is going to go, and just don't care about it the whole time. I couldn't sit still in the theatre because all I wanted to do was leave, which half the theatre did already by the end of the movie so it wasn't just me. Please don't do a sequel.

Wes Anderson gives us a creative comedy, directed by charismatic characters with a political and satirical background.
The basis of the film is the animation, the artistic direction and especially the sound that is Is in charge of the Oscar-winning Desplat.
The narration of the film is perfectly taken, the important moments stand out, especially the flashbacks. The structure of the story helps to communicate as quickly as possible, this helps you to return to the extravagant characters and landscapes. 
The story, beyond being ridiculous and dissociating from reality is used to attract the viewer to it. After a certain moment you accept the strange rhythm and the accelerated editing style that the film has.
Once you accept it, the film takes you to an audiovisual experience so hypnotic that you do not want it to end. The negative note is the lack of originality that makes us think of something like "this already seen".
In summary, one of the three best films of Wes Anderson.

reviews.review_title: Isle of Dogs vs Hollywood Blockbusters
reviews.content:
It is no surprise that a Wes Anderson film is good anymore, because let's face it, the guy knows what he's doing.
What I loved most about "Isle of Dogs" though, was the script. It is far more insightful than anything that's out there right now, because of the level of CARE that Anderson puts into the story, the characters and their development, and the MESSAGE he wants his audience to take home with them.
Over the last few years there's been a lack of good writing in the movie industry (specially in Hollywood). This has not been true for TV, though. Although most serious screenwriters have moved onto television, this is not because they earn more money, or they can't get jobs in films, it is simply because TV producers are caring more about the scripts than movie studios.
Remember when the story mattered? When it wasn't about visual effects or how many screens a distributor could get for your film? Well, for a moment yesterday, "Isle of Dogs" transported me to that era. The era of "Shine" or "Jerry Maguire"... when movies that made money at the box office actually struggled to get a lot of screens, but climbed their way to the top for one simple reason: GOOD STORYTELLING.
Nowadays, good vfx or good advertising have overcome good storytelling. Think about it. Do you really believe that "Infinity War" would have been more successful than, say, "Schindler's List" back when good storytelling was what made the difference? The more admirable production value "Infinity War" has is the gigantic distribution it was given. When you go to the theaters and all you can watch is the new sequel to the Avengers... you'll end up watching that because you have NO MORE CHOICES. But back then, when you actually had options, when your film was screening at the same time than "The Fugitive" or "The Nightmare Before Christmas", it was a BIG DEAL to be number one at the box office, because it meant that your film was most likely, the best film screening at the time, and not the one with more money spent in advertising and distribution. All these new "infinite sequels" are doing is spoiling the audience's taste and right to cinematic cultural diversity.
I'm not saying there shouldn't be any Avengers films. I'm simply saying there should always be more options for our audiences to watch, because, as you all know, once a film is cut out of the theaters, it most likely will never be screened there again. And when exhibitors permit that one film is shown in the vast majority of theaters, that means that a whole lot of good movies are going to be cut out, and people are going to lose a chance to watch them in the big screen.
Imagine if you never got a chance to watch "Fargo" in the movie theaters because "Titanic" was the only film showing. Imagine not being able to watch "As good as it gets" because the distributor for "Men in Black" kicked everything else out of the theaters. Thank God that didn't happen back then. Because they are all great films, and should be given a chance to be enjoyed by the audience. But nowadays, it seems that it's all about marketing and making money, and it is not about content anymore. It is not about the stories.
If you are a true believer in cinema, and in the power that a good film has to change, not only perspectives, but PEOPLE'S LIVES, then you should definitely watch "Isle of Dogs." If all you care about are sequels and visual effects, and scripts without purpose or message, then this film will probably seem boring to you, but you should give it a chance anyway, because everyone else gives a chance to the movies you like (we mostly don't have a choice anymore.)

Wes Anderson movies are a miracle to me. His shot composition is so different and original that I don't know how it can even work in a coherent movie. And what's fascinating to me is that the longer he does it the better and more refined he gets, never compromising to anyone or anything, always staying true to his vision. This movie is a marvel to look at. Everything is so meticulously well constructed, every shot so detailed that the only bad thing I can say is that sometimes I longed for a pause button so that I could appreciate all the details he put into all the shots. But it's not only at a cinematography level that his movies work, I would argue that he excels at every aspect of filmmaking, like the use of music and editing to further enhance his vision. But all of this would be for nothing if the movie didn't work on a story level, and here is where some of his movies sometimes fail, but that is not the case here, as I found everything almost perfect with this near future tale of a boy trying to set things right in a world that wants to get rid of dogs. A love letter to both dogs and Japan. Loved it.

Really good story and delivered very well, i kindda expect some beutiful scene like kubo but Isle of Dog has it's own way to show it. like the sushi part, yeah that's pretty beautifuly satisfied hhahathe whole movie will constantly suprised you. they doing it really good, gave it part by part so it's not to much and still can be acceptable all the way till the end.i guess this is one of the 2018 best movie.
This could've been a great movie if Hollywood wasn't so preoccupied with pushing agendas. Get back to good storytelling.

reviews.review_title: Artsy fun but lacks character and plot
reviews.content: I find Isle of Dogs to be one of the most visually and aesthetically striking movies to exist. There were so many sequences that made me audibly say "wow". It's definitely supposed to be a movie that looked cool, and while it does do that, it doesn't deliver on the writing. The biggest downfall of the writing is the characters. The characters are one dimensional and boring. The movie expects us to feel something for them, but honestly I don't. Overall, Isle of Dogs creates inspiration and not emotion.

reviews.review_title: A Breath of Fresh Air in the Genre of Children's Animation
reviews.content: Fantastic Mr Fox is one of my favourite films so when I heard that Wes Anderson was going to be making another stop-motion movie I was beyond myself with excitement, however, stuff comes up you get busy and next thing you know 4 years have passed. Finally I managed to get round to watching the film and while it wasn't as good as FMF it was still a great time and another brilliant example of how stop-motion is such an underutilized medium.The story is weird, it's about Japan sending all it's dogs to an island due to an illness, the "dog flu", and a boy travelling there to try and find his lost dog. The story is, as I said, weird but nonetheless thoroughly entertaining, every scene is beautifully shot and the voice talent is highly enjoyable with some massive stars being a part of the cast. I will say that as the film is set in Japan some dialogue is in unsubbed Japanese, not huge amounts and not in a way that makes it difficult to understand the story but it does make me wonder if this may turn younger children off of the film. Still for me I though it was great at setting tone and demonstrated how brilliantly Wes could tell portions of the story through nothing but the visuals. The animation here is delightful, very similar in style to Fantastic Mr Fox but different enough that it doesn't feel like the same universe. A brilliant film with very few flaws overall, enjoyable for any age and a breath of fresh air in the genre of children's animation. 8/10.

It's got that film festival energy to it, and has the Wes Anderson charm but something is missing. Maybe it's some characters aren't very memorable and some feel unimportant to the story, but in the end it's still a good movie.

reviews.review_title: wes anderson + the same cast x lots of dogs = good movie
reviews.content: I mean gow could you not love edward nortans charecter rex or chief this film is so uniqe and good i reccomend
Unmistakably Wes Anderson in every way; wonderfully enjoyable with engaging characters & an unflinching cadence; plus, for once, I didn't outright loathe Greta Gerwig.

In true Wes Anderson fashion we are treated to another feel good and whimsical tale of a boy and his best friend. The voice acting and animation for this movie was great, very fluid motions and fitting voice acting. Isle of Dogs was designed to be pleasing and to invoke a warm smile in its audiences. But at the same time delivering its message of companionship, the relationship and bond between man and man's best friend.I can't help but be reminded of the not so successful Alpha that executes this theme rather poorly. While that movie chooses to focus on the grand scopes and large wild plains and tell this lengthy story, Isle of Dogs takes a completely different approach. It focuses solely on a brief relationship between Chief and Atari, making it a lot more relatable and thus a much more accepted message.This was a movie that felt fun and exciting when dealing with serious issues, a trademark of Wes Anderson's cinema at this point. A wonderful movie that delivers a message for both children and adult audiences.

reviews.review_title: How can you be sexist with dogs? Here's how
reviews.content: Even when he's directing a bunch of stop-motion dogs, Wes Anderson manages to cast thin blondes and give them characters with zero personality.This is a technically pretty film, and full of the kind of unchecked, unadressed patriarchy & western worldview that is often mistaken for neutrality & objectivity. Shrouded in Anderson's typical whimsy, this content is even more harmful because of its palatability.Disappointing, frustrating and sad.

Isle of Dogs is an animated film about a Japanese city in the future blaming dogs for the major diseases and banishing them all to an island full of garbage. Left to fend for themselves, things take a turn when the Mayor's son arrives there in secret to find his beloved dog.I'm still somewhat on the fence with regards to Wes Anderson's films, marmite as they are... and this effort has done little to sway me either way. The animated style makes me think if Tim Burton made an episode of Wallace & Gromit, and Wes' trademark style of realistic conversation with long pauses creates a lot of awkward silences and irregular pacing. The look of the film is at odds with the tone which doesn't help, but dispite all that the story is interesting and the vocal talents on desplay from the star studded cast keep you engaged even if something is... off with the whole thing. Fans of Wes Anderson could bump my score up a number, but for everyone else this is a passable, if unessential watch.

reviews.review_title: This canine-themed stop-motion beast wags its tail because of Anderson's filmmaking loftiness
reviews.content:
Wes Anderson is not a cult artist, he's a prolific maestro. His films always enjoy an added cachet that positions them far above many only-entertainment flicks, and his latest classical animated jewel meets perfectly what one would expect from an indie author who has erected his sublime filmography frame by frame. It's neither a blatant cultural appropriation of East Asian culture nor a scurrilous Japanese stereotyped assortment drawn by an injurious foreigner, it's a beautifully hand-made and delicate love story, a widely different, a fertile pic in visible and veiled exclamations on freedom, press, politics, principles, fear, transformation, friendship and human and dog's life which feeds off from a top-of-the-range vocal cast and a visual and technical section as eccentric and neat as every of the narrative ambitions of a filmmaker who not only sets up a baroque addition to his exquisite filmography and artistic growth but imbues this high-concept film, with some complacency, of a razor-sharp, sophisticated allegory that is clearly geared to the grown-up minds, those who resist to consider art as a channel of trivial thoughts, not as a mechanism of inescapable contact and advancement. There's no doubt that for Anderson's style newcomers the first thing they will highlight is tangibility of the pictures. Getting into the multiplex with a pre-established idea about how "Fantastic Mr. Fox" director works is not helpful to prepare the senses, because it'd be minimizing part of their huge effort, every drop of beauty emerging from the screen is commendable, it's pure marvel. When the screening was over, the up-front reference that arose in my mind was the most recent piece of art of Laika Entertainment, "Kubo and the Two Strings," not precisely by the concordance with the cultural basis or some moral similarities, but by the beautifully crafted creations, by being an invaluable gift for cinema, by the unspeakable visual prowess that hundreds of artists have built for us. The symmetrical compositions of the ever-perfectionist director who refuses to subdue his works under the phenomena of the digital age are straightforwardly glittering; a sharper aim to circumvent known superficialities and immerse it into the complicated, visually speaking, Japanese pulp places this film on a higher level in artistic terms, even unfolding the majority of the action on an adjacent island. Detail transmutes into obsession with the slightest manifestation of sumptuousness; the naturalness in its moves dazzles our perceptions which try to stumble upon a broken sequence, a malicious desire that, obviously, never will come true with Anderson at the helm. There are few human beings walking through the story because the canine leads are the ones who get most of the attention of the art departments; the dog's actions and activities enhance the progress of the plot thanks to the veracity of their behaviors, the domesticated animal par excellence is really here beyond the nearly human behavior given to them. More broadly, what decorates with personality the feast of strangely gorgeous frames is incredible and awardable cinematographer Tristan Oliver, rich in nuances and recesses endowing the pictures with irrepressible force which grows uncontrollably as the film runs, every frame is an authentic, finely crafted and shaped sculpture passing through the hands of hundreds of exquisite animators who with their talent, literally and figuratively, capture the obsessions of an animation maestro; a spellbinding experience. It's worth highlighting the majestic score by the most recent Oscar winner for Best Original Score Alexandre Desplat, who again is running for a golden nomination in the awards. Like Ludwig Göransson for Marvel Studios' "Black Panther," he's a composer who knows how to channel well traditional drum sounds and Oriental instruments in which the feature film develops, he mixes them with his own ideas, creating a portentous whole, here, musical accompaniment is vital for the sensory process in the cinematic experience; his score is volatile, energetic and powerful, but at the same time fine, sensitive and adequate, candid and completely exciting. 
Anderson isn't only known for his peculiar and unpractical but extremely gratifying filming method, the textual motives that mobilize such handmade constructions intervene in the success of the narrations. The script is written undeniable by the American director because the characteristics of a concise writer arise, sensitive in a given moment, but coolly manipulative when the film itself requires it. With regard to the dicey, well-intentioned plot, it's conceived by eight hands with own name and recognition: Kunichi Nomura, in his first work as a writer; Jason Schwartzman, in his third experience as a film screenwriter; Roman Coppola, in one of the greatest successes of his career; and Wes Anderson, a man who doesn't need a description, just run and get covered with his artistic visions. The perspective he gives the story is simply unique, social and pleasantly revitalizing not only due to the fussy field of animation but the drama genre lines it uses with an unusual confidence in levels of conviction and coherence with respect to a plot that doesn't set in an explicitly human context, in the strictest sense of the word. The spark of the script gives brilliance to the plot needs and intransigent twists, besides, comedy is handled surgically in the narrative, becoming it a crucial point on the mere fact that the gradual and unexpected humor threads compose and speed up the pace of a non-commercial film, one that does have to defend against other mega-budget opponents. The most unfocused and less determined who attend the multiplex will delight with the elements manufacturing a beautiful surface, however, the most observant and connoisseurs of the filmmaker's style will get out of the theater with a radically different perception, a sharper, more complicated and risky one that touched on polarizing and delicate current problems concerning the whole world. In addition to its frank animalistic message, the script keeps going its critical purpose in every approach it proposes, criticisms that never boss around the characters to get their tasks, but rather they boss around every spectator's intellect to try to play with what it considers to be right and wrong, ironically, expressed through a canine tale. 
Generally speaking, Anderson delivers an editing style I have never seen before, telling his story in two languages (English and Japanese) and opposing completely to dubbing, he warns with complacency, after the unforgettable opening credits, the way how he will approach the narrative, presenting the rules of the universe he created and you have to accept to get lost in, whether you want or not. The film always gets a way to literally translate most of the foreign dialogue, however, it's here where his filmmaking method comes into play to underline that the most important characters are the animals, the Americanized canines, who capture all their attention and effort. It's also widely appreciated the work done by the incorrigible voices of post-modern American and European acting patrons and matrons- it's not really difficult to hide the disparity between men and women again. - Bryan Cranston, Edward Norton, Bill Murray, Greta Gerwig, Frances McDormand, Tilda Swinton and Scarlett Johansson or important Oriental exponents such as Yoko Ono, Kunichi Nomura or young player Koyu Rankin perform a dubbing work motivated by dedication, enthusiasm and, of course, the pride of joinig forces with one of the most old-school and perfectionist directors currently working. The excellent vocal cast is undoubtedly one of the strengths and main thrusters for the organic, charismatic and dynamic functioning of the ambitious idea.
"Isle of Dogs" by Wes Anderson mesmerizes from beginning to end, partly by its mania of playing with the high expectations always put on a director's job. Accessible and sophisticated, strategic and human, hilarious and dramatic, strangely beautiful and directed; this animated film is an undeniable love letter from the filmmaker to Oriental culture, canines and, beyond doubt, the recesses and perversities of the feelings, actions and inspirations of humankind; A feature film that produce juicy critical, controversial commentaries through generally opposed elements that are quickly woven on a story led by any manifestation of love, prioritizing narrative, technical and artistic fields with the proportionality only a maestro could handle. If you want to enjoy a good movie you will have many more options to choose from, but if you demand a top-notch film you will be welcome to watch as a stop-motion animation monster puts an actor, screenwriter, producer and director- uninterested in making movies for an Oscar - on the front page, a place he has never gotten out from.

reviews.review_title: This movie is spectacular. The animation is some of the best I've ever seen!
reviews.content: I guess that Wes Anderson is incapable of making a bad movie. As simple and childish this movie might seem to you, it's everything but that. It's like a modern age animal farm a poignant epopé about freedom, propaganda, and tyranny against democracy. One of the many things that attracted me about this movie is how alive and human this puppets and dogs are especially the dogs, they feel alive and they're very attachable, moving and funny (the way they vote to decide at any situation is very charming and clever) and I guess it's done on purpose to make you wonder how no one except atari noticed that and set them as the representatives of democracy aka freedom from the beginning. I must also praise the voice acting Ed Norton, Brian Cranston and Bill Murray can deliver a heavily charged humorous and touching performances only relying on their voices, I was mesmerized. The other thing that impressed me with this movie is how beautiful and original this world and story are with this fictional Japan stuck between the future and the past plus the manner Wes managed to convey a complex and thorny message through a funny, simple and gratifying story is border genius. Add to it his iconic romantic touch and directing that make the best out of this epic. I promise you won't be able to lift your eyes for a second, it's by far one of the best movies of the year.

reviews.review_title: A Stop-motion spectacle both in art and storytelling
reviews.content: In a similar vein to his work on the brilliant Fantastic Mr Fox (2009), Wes Anderson has delved back into the painstaking art of stop-motion film, and with great success. Isle of Dogs is an artistic vision that requires a very particular talent to construct, using Anderson's mastery of colour palettes to recreate a gritty, unclean world that still holds its charm. The story follows a group of banished canines helping a boy find his own dog, all whilst trying to avoid the extermination of their species. Set in a modern-day Japan (and on an island made exclusively of rubbish), stop-motion gives the film more refinement than you would be able to generate via GCI, enhancing the personal feel of the spectacle.It feels as if Anderson has pored over every frame, secreting hidden details to give the more attentive viewer a rewarding experience. Further to this, the use of authentic Japanese text and speech means the departure from the location isn't too extreme for a largely foreign viewership. Anderson's casts are always exemplary: Bryan Cranston, Edward Norton, Jeff Goldblum, Bill Murray and Scarlett Johansson all lend their voices to various characters, each adding individual quirks to their respective roles. Their animations are all so clean and precise, highlighting the true quality of the animation team.Isle of Dogs caters for virtually any audience, containing elements to entertain adults and younger generations alike. The journey around this fabricate world is a story in itself, making Isle of Dogs a rare example of a film that creates a truly immersive environment, as well as delivering with a quality story.
There are just not enough stars to express how much I loved this movie. Wes Anderson has done it yet again.

reviews.review_title: Killing me slowly with this movie
reviews.content: I had to turn off this movie within 10 mins, it did not make any sense.

Must be hell working for Wes Anderson, the obsessive, compulsive movie maker who carefully sculpts each and every frame, and meticulously fills it with excruciating detail. Thankfully most of us are in the audience instead, which means a totally opposite, enjoyable experience.As with all past efforts, "Isle of Dogs" is a staggering visual feast, and because this is animation (a stop motion, retro futuristic, Japanese one), it is chock full of exquisite canvasses, complex graphics, and stunning originality. It's easy to get caught up in the eye candy, but what is truly revelatory here is the stunning audio that envelops the theatre. Remember all that fuss about surround sound? Well, we finally have proper use, and with several instances - a fabulous drumming sequence, and a haunting dog howling - it is glorious.Oh there's a story as well, which is the usual, meandering vehicle that strings together all the fun bits, and is perhaps the most traditional of Anderson's jaggedy plot lines. Plus it's full of dogs. Superb.

reviews.review_title: Colorful, slightly annoying but endearing Wes Anderson fable
reviews.content: Wes Anderson's homage to Japanese film animation certainly has its good points. It's visually elaborate and depicted in alternatingly desolate and pristine landscapes in fictitious places in Japan. The incredible thing about Anderson's work is that even a story about dogs being quarantined on a toxic waste island can seem momentous and even highbrow with his upright, stubbornly eccentric style of filmmaking.Initially, this wasn't quite my speed. I found the film's beginning a bit lacking in its emotional pull even with a fairly thorough backstory about the five dogs who become the pack at the center of the story and a boy who flies to the island where the dogs have been isolated. Fortunately, the film becomes considerably more compelling once it becomes clear what the boy's purpose is and how much he is up against. The plot aspect involving a corrupt, tyrannical mayor of a large fictitious Japanese city is one of the more enjoyable parts of the storyline.I was ultimately able to digest this film because I settled into it and just decided to run with its mad adventure and its dogged (no pun intended) fight against political corruption and anti-democratic practices. The political aspect of the story made this film more fascinating and worthwhile. Having said that, a couple of the human supporting characters are so cardboard and disposable that it might make the viewer regard Trash Island as more a refuge than a prison.My friend who saw this with me described the film as "too precious" to connect with (a common criticism that Anderson films sometimes run into) and concluded that it was ultimately "superficial" after a promising start. If you're not a Wes Anderson devotee, you might conclude that this film either squanders or redeems itself. In the end, I found it adequate enough to recommend.

I think that all you doggie people would live to watch this movie about ceiling dogs! At first glance you see right away a plague has broken out among the canines. Secondly, people have banished all said canines to the Isle of Dogs. This is to prevent the spreading of Snout Fever to humans. The dogs, at first, fight over resources, as predicted. Human are scared of their once best friends.... You must watch this clever Japanese anime in length on Disney this month. Its great! If you're an animal lover as I, you'll be pleased with this foreign film. All humans and their dogs speak the untold language of love through Millennium. This twist on a sad tale from the future will bring tears to your eyes of love, loyalty and perseverance as even Jack London would have appreciated. Pax, Murf Pax and Amore, Murf
As usual, Anderson delivers an incredibly well-directed film with an incredible screenplay.

I watched the the new Wes Anderson movie Isle of Dogs. I'm a big Wes Anderson fan so I walked into the movie knowing I was going to like it. Of course I was not disappointed.Similar to his other work Fantastic Mr. Fox the claymation was outstanding. The movie was a joy to watch from start to finish.As always the movie had a quirky sense of humor that is typical of Wes Anderson films. I particularly enjoyed the music which really fit well with the flow of the film.The story was original and kept me entertained the entire time. Wes Anderson's strongest selling point is normally his characters and he did not disappoint on this movie either. The voice acting was outstanding all around. Each character had a distinct voice and personality. The back-and-forth character interactions were probably the best part of the movie.Overall I really enjoyed it, but you have to be a Wes Anderson fan. His directing style is very distinct and follows a specific pattern. Isle of Dogs definitely did not break any new ground. His quirky directing style is a plus for me as a fan and the movie was fun all around. I really enjoyed it a 8.25 out of 10.

Being a dog lover and fan of all Wes Anderson's work, I remain unbiased. Simply put this is classic Anderson. It displays all of his idiosyncrasies. It's witty, clever, smart and heartfelt. The animation is visually captivating. The plot revolves around a young boy who travels to Trash Island where all dogs have been exiled to find his bodyguard dog or in this case his best friend. There he meets a pack of mongrel dogs who decide to help him in his search. That is where the joy ride begins. The ending has a heartwarming twist that touches on what many humans believe. It doesn't seem to matter if Anderson's art is displayed by actors on film or animation. This unique director continues to impress and shine. It's no surprise artist continue to collaborate with him on projects. It reminded me off how dogs often times display more humanity than we do. Dogs truely are our best friends and Wes reminds us of this fact.This is one of his best works to date. His vision is a brilliant commentary on us.

I like Wes Anderson. Scorsese also said that his favorite director was Wes Anderson. Unfortunately, his latest films are far from his first creative work. That's not a bad movie. But, It's not a movie that wes anderson looks good.

Isle of Dogs, or maybe more obviously Wes Anderson meant "I Love Dogs," is a vapid story, oddly enough written by four people. One would think a story so plain would need but one writer, yet we have four, which might explain why the movie is little more than a beautiful animation.No offense, Mr. Anderson, but Roald Dahl wrote better stories, and you're beginning to perfect stop-motion animation, with particular excellence for sushi, explosions, dog fights, and kidney surgeries. What's a bit strange is the relatively small number of types of dogs represented on Trash Island, nearly all of them male dogs, nearly all of them looking something like a terrier.There must be some sort of morality play going on with the legend of cats versus dogs, a beheading, and a link between ecology and disease. Or maybe it's something more current, some message about exiling unwanted animals akin to keeping refugees or immigrants at bay, away from us, hidden from view so we no longer have to deal with them, because they were never human in the first place.The voice acting is as good as you would expect, even with the clever casting of Yoko Ono as Assistant Scientist Yoko Ono, and even better use of F. Murray Abraham and Harvey Keitel. Although I love dogs, Isle of Dogs is not really about dogs at all, is it?

reviews.review_title: Whatever happened to man's best friend?
reviews.content: I love dogs and I love Japanese culture... and this movie has both!The movie is a visual marvel, is a real spectacle to the eyes. The dogs are lovely, specially their eyes which are always full of emotion. A few scenes should be in a museum, as they are true pieces of art; for example the sushi cooking and the operation of Atari and the mayor Kobayashi. These scenes also represent the discipline and search of perfection in which most Japanese do every task.The story is easy to comprehend. I didn't like that the original pack of dogs (Rex, Boss, Duke, King and Chief) looses their role as the film moves forward, with the exception of Chief, but that is for Spots to shine. The character of Atari was really ambiguous, sometimes I felt that he was evil as his uncle... maybe all dogs sometimes have that fear for their masters.I personally like the representation of the Japanese culture, but I believe it was exaggerated sometimes. Also, there were too many scenes in Japanese without translation and that made the movie a bit dense.Finall, I loved the reaction of the pack of dogs to the arrival of Atari, as it represents that a dog will never betray their masters, regardless what is done to them. They loyalty is unbreakable.

Audiences around the world go to see a Wes Anderson film for many reasons; imagination, creativity, wonder and most of all, amazement. A man who has crafted and added to, not only a branch of the film industry within the independent market, but an individual who arguable has his own genre of film, proves with his latest that you are able to make an independent success, commercial darling and fading animation style feature film revolutionary. After eight feature films which enrich the medium as a whole, Wes Anderson delved, for a second time, into the stop-motion foray with his ninth future film, and quite possibly his best yet with Isle of Dogs. You heard the rumours right? About Isle of Dogs? Sure, there are a ton of rumours, controversy and discussions about the auteur director's latest film, both positive and negative (which we will discuss further into this review) including some fun facts that if you say the film's title fast, it's actually the equivalent of saying "I Love Dogs", as well as arguments about cultural appropriation, hmmm.The fact of the matter is, first and foremost, Isle of Dogs is a film that pays tribute and homage to so many of the things that Anderson loves and hold very dear to his heart. From his love to canines, to his homages to legendary filmmakers and vanguards Hayao Miyazaki and Akira Kurosawa, to his love of stop-motion animation; Anderson's second venture into stop-motion animation is a film anchored by his passions, as well as a TRUE film for dog-lovers everywhere.
