I didn't like how they split it into chapters, they didn't really need to do that and I feel like the narrator was unoriginal and I feel like they could have done something a bit more creative. Also the puffy girl character could have done more, because she didn't really do as much as she should have done in the amount of time that they gave her. That is basically everything I have to say about this movie, I think it is great and if you haven't seen it, then do see it. It is really enjoyable and I loved it, but this is not a kid's movie.
Good movie, would recommend, good family movie too
There's so much to love about Isle of Dogs. From its gorgeous stop-motion animation style, beautiful cinematography and great characters, Wes Anderson excels in telling his greatest story to date.

reviews.review_title: If you ready not to waist your time, sit down and watch!
reviews.content: Three hours ago, I just did one of the best decision in my past year. I went to watch #IsleOfDogs. I surely recommend it to you too. One of the best-animated movies in past few years. Directed and written by #WesAnderson as well he directed #GrandBudapestHotel. It is amazingly written, with so much detail, humour will be acceptable to these kind of people who like something more than dumb and dumber, it is very creative and it's hard to blink because you don't want to miss a second in this movie from beginning to the end. So sit down and enjoy the originality of this movie and how strangely warm it makes you smile hour after the movie was finished.I am giving 10* of 10* on IMDb and it's already 8.2*.

If you know me, you know how much of a fan I am of Wes Anderson, and this animated spectacular has only solidified my opinion further. A cast of this level can often be messy and incoherent when put together, a problem not apparent to Anderson, however. Isle of Dogs is witty, has a strong and coherent story line and despite being longer than most Wes Anderson films, does not lose its excellent storytelling and continuous viewer entertainment. A star-studded cast lose none of their quality performing as voice-actors, this film is simply brilliant. Without a doubt this is now one of my favourite animated features ever. The animation although unorthodox is intriguing and different, the breath of fresh air often displayed by Anderson continues to breathe, and long may it continue.
Different isn't always good, but in Wes Anderson's case, different is absolutely fantastic.
(By the way... Have you heard the rumour?)

I'm not a huge Wes Anderson fan, but I do enjoy one or three of his films. Stop motion animation throws Anderson's usual quirks into a feverish overdrive. But this story is absolutely adorable and worth your time! The voice acting is fantastic! Seriously go watch this movie.
This movie is very boring. Do yourself a favor by skipping this one.
This was a really good movie. It wasn't your adverse typical cute dog movie, it had meaning. I loved it.
The cultural crossover was brilliant, and much of the quirky, ironic humour was spot on. Story a little predictable, but that's not the end of the world.
Loved the visuals and the use of language in this movie.

This is an amazing movie. After Fantastic Mr Fox, I thought Wes Anderson was done with the medium of animation. I thought he couldn't make a comeback, because I hated Moonrise Kingdom and thought Grand Budapest Hotel wasn't his best movie. The great thing about this movie is that it doesn't rely on cliches. Most of Wes's films are comedies, but I find this one to be more of a drama. The untranslated Japanese offers actually made me connect MORE to the characters, because I can relate through more subtle means. This is a very subtle movie, so if you like blockbusters a lot, you'll probably hate this. The political allegory is very strong and relevant and capturing it through the lens of a 12 year old helps understand it from all point of view's. Atari's story has a happy ending, but the movie makes clear that the dog flu isn't the only political conspiracy in Japan. I loved all the characters, but Chief seemed to represent most a great character journey. He goes from being a stray, and hating humans, to starting to like Atari, to becoming his new dog at the end. It was a very interesting character journey, especially since Chief spoke in English. I loved the movie. Highly recommended
This stop motion animation is masterfully done and the storyline and production are amazing.

Visuals: Not much to say other then the animation very good/smooth. Directing/cinematography was very Wes Anderson, and goes hand-in-hand with stop motion.Audio: All voices fit with characters well. Music was fitting/good, not amazing. Lack of subtitles was annoying in some parts, but translations were there when necessary. When there weren't any, like with most of the government leaders dialogue, they did a good job of displaying his emotions which still got out the main points.Plot: Worked very well with the setting/art style. Pseudo antagonist redemption at the end felt rushed but was understandable. Beginning was focused on Main character with the group of five dogs. Second was focused on secondary character (Afro girl) and Atari fighting (separately) against government as well as the dog brother subplot. Ending was cute and did a good job of taking very subtle plot points and bringing them to the fore front (hacker dude from Afro girls high school for example)Characters: The kid and the Main dog had a surprisingly good chemistry that kinda came out of nowhere towards the end. The scene where they first get separated from the rest of the group is one of the best. It's the biggest character developing section and does a good job of showing why they become so close towards the end. The other dogs in the group served there purpose, but were somewhat forgettable in the third act. The Afro girl wasn't exactly necessary, but was a definite net positive on the movie.+Art Style
+Performances
+Directing
+Solid Character Chemistry
=Average sounds design
-Disregard of Characters in the Third Act

I love the visuals of Wes Anderson movies. He is one of my favourite directors. The colors, the setup, the paintings, the alignments and silhouettes. Isle of dogs is no exception. But! This is a movie made by men for men. Lead and most supporting characters are male. Animals that usually have no sex are male. The owl is referred to as he, almost all the dogs have male voices. There are only three female dogs, first is the beautiful show dog, the second the motherly dog that instantly gets pregant and whos only role is to nurture, build a family and admire the male family dog, the third is the so-called oracle who only watches TV all day and stands next to the bigger, respected organising alpha male dog.Then there are three female human characters. One girl that actually says that she is in love with Atari although that contributes nothing to the story, the female scientist who can't manage her life without her male achiever colleague who commits suicide and the female translator who, well, at least works and does not talk about men and their superiority/manlihood all the time but also doesn't contribute anything to the progress of the movie other than commenting and translating to the audience.Wes Anderson knows better to write for stronger, more diverse roles. The actors/voices (Scarlett, Tolda, Greta - really?) know better to demand better female roles and dialogs. And the audience knows better not to vote 10 stars when it only has 0-star-female characters in it.

reviews.review_title: I cried when I watched it in theaters! Love this so much!
reviews.content: I love this movie so much that I bought it as soon as I could. It hurts my heart how could people be so awful to such a wonderful beings that are our best friends. If you love animals please go out and watch this! Its a awesome tale of a boy and his best friend! Its sad, happy, heartfelt, and sweet! Go buy it today if you are a Wes Anderson fan because it's worth it!!

A little boring, it is good for teenagers.i expect more amuzing movie with rating at 7.8
The subject is good by itself but play different
This movie was so visually beautiful, i had to watch it twice in the same day because i was so caught up with visuals the first time round.

reviews.review_title: Awesome movie and with dogs even better
reviews.content:
Island of dogs

Wes Anderson is not a cult artist, he is a prolific master. His films always enjoy an added prestige that places them far above many films of mere entertainment, and his latest stop-motion gem fulfills perfectly what one would expect from an indie author who has erected his sublime filmography frame by frame. It is not a shameless cultural appropriation or fetishization, much less an orgy of Japanese stereotypes marked by a foreign bear, it is a beautiful and delicate love story, a widely different one, rich in visible and veiled exclamations about freedom, the press, politics, principles, fear, transformation, The friendship and the human and canine life that feeds on a first-rate vocal cast and a visual and technical section as eccentric and verbose as each of the narrative ambitions of a filmmaker who not only builds a complex addition to his exquisite filmography and artistic growth but imbues with a certain complacency a sharp and intelligent allegory into a high concept film that is clearly aimed at older minds, Those who resist to think of art as a channel of insurmountable thoughts, not as a mechanism of unavoidable contact and advancement.

This was a fun film, with serious and relevant undertones. The dogs are typical Wes Anderson characters and have the kind of wry viewpoints and wit that we've all come to enjoy in his films. The rich visual detail in all of the sets and backdrops are a joy to view and will bear repeated viewings. The story is indeed somewhat slight, and the constant underscore can get in the way on occasion.(And cat lovers will hate it)But if you've read the prejudiced review on Roger Ebert's site, you are in for a lovely surprise - this is a very fine film. Not Anderson's best, but an excellent film

I absolutely loved this film. The art was so good, music brilliant, great story, so creative, and funny. I can't wait to get a copy for home once it's available. I think it will reward multiple viewings.
Without giving in to watching any trailers for this particular movie, I was in high hopes to be pleasantly surprised and amused. I truly was! Quite quick but very sincere.
This does for stop motion now what Nightmare Before Christmas did when it came out. Style, art, and a blend of seriousness and whimsy.

The concept itself is fairly simple, but it DEFINITELY makes up for it in cinematography and aesthetics. The soundtrack is gorgeous and very well timed at many points in the film. Clearly something that the team was very passionate about.

Wes Anderson proves his newly-discovered talents for blending animation and storytelling, comedy and relevance, heart and humour in his second stop-motion picture. 20 human years into the future (not certain about dog years) a breakout of dog flue in the Japanese city of Negasaki has 'forced' the government to banish all dogs to Trash Island. There, the dogs form their own savage society until Atari (Kuyo Rankin) tumbles in in search of his dog.What is perhaps most wonderful about this film is the beauty of it. Each and every dog has been given equal care and effort in creation and each look is scruffy yet loveable. The audience therefore, cannot help but fall in love with each K-9 character they meet. Hearing the words 'Trash Island' used to describe the film's setting would usually be enough to put anyone off yet Anderson surprises audiences. The trash is colour correlated and arranged in such ways that resemble the beauties of modern society and bring a strange charm to the world of the film. A cave the leading dogs have built for themselves comes to mind; the whole thing built out of empty bottles of various colours. This makes it resemble a jewel cave or something even more wonderful. Such care in setting is accommodated by a carefully chosen cast. Actors such as Bryan Cranston, Jeff Goldblum and Tilda Swinton allow themselves just enough freedom to develop individual characters. We hardly have time to get to know anyone with the speed of the film, yet the independent quirks of each dog allow just enough life and wit to be given. Most of the humour derives from rather dark jokes bordering around animal cruelty and certain injustices in Japanese culture. An example being a chef preparing sushi dinner and, in the process, carving open the head of a still-alive crab. Another being the dogs gossiping about the miserable and suicidal way that one of their comrades lost his life. These quirks seem like Anderson's way of making small statements about human's powerful ability to be cruel to creatures we deem as less powerful than ourselves. After all, what's crueller than abandoning sick puppies on a dirty and disease-ridden island? Anderson still pays tribute to the culture he toys with by presenting Kabuki dances and having his human characters speak their native tongue. Their own injustices are still there however, and its evident the thesis he attempts to present about human nature.Of-course not all the jokes are this dark. Most of the humans in the film are presented as silly using fast-paced slapstick actions. Most of this humour derives from its own unexpectedness and thus, should not be spoiled in a review. The quirks balance out the darkness in the film and ensure that the audience keeps laughing and involved in the film. All other social statements aside, this is a tale about a dog's loyalty to his master. Watching the friendships develop between the dogs and Atari demonstrates this love and ties together all other themes explored. Ultimately, leaving audiences with a sense of hope as they leave the cinema. The only downside to the film is a somewhat abrupt and unrealistic ending. The ending does tie up loose ends yet gives everything to its main characters from basically nothing. Does this contribute to any morals or themes of the film? It'll need to be up to the audience to tell. Wes Anderson is famed and glorified for his strange and unique creative style. Isle of Dogs is perhaps his strangest and yet one of his best. With humour and flair, the film speaks up for those who cannot speak for themselves and ensures laughs from audiences pro-dog and not. Out of Five: 4 StarsDid you know: Jeff Goldblum recorded his lines over the phone due to scheduling conflicts with another film.

I would not consider myself a Wes Anderson fanatic like some people would, but I certainly do enjoy his films. In an era of big budget superhero movies dominating the box office, it is refreshing to see someone with such a unique vision continuing to thrive. His latest effort, Isle of Dogs, is no exception to his commitment of great film making. Anderson's style translates extremely well to this type of story; simple yet entertaining at its core. His technical precision, comedic timing, camera movement, and quick editing elevates a timeless plot into something truly captivating. The star of the show is the quality of the animation. This is Anderson's sophomore effort into the medium (the first being 2009's "Fantastic Mr. Fox") and he has yet again achieved something remarkable. His team's effort to make the animation look flawless absolutely translates to the screen while viewing this film. The voice acting for the most part is done well. While I take some issue with almost exclusively casting well know actors to play these characters, overall they did a good job. Bryan Cranston is the real standout here, as his gravely voice and intensity fits the character he is playing. He voices a dog named Chief and his character arc, as well as his relationship with the young protagonist, Atari, are the emotion core of the movie. Their dynamic has been seen before but is really well executed through the animation and voice performances. Despite these positives and my overall enjoyment of the movie, there are some negatives to the movie. The dialogue can very often fall into the cliche or hokey category which is not atypical for a Wes Anderson film. He writes his films purposely deadpan which is acceptable but this, however, causes some of the jokes to misfire or completely miss the mark and could be solved with a change in style. That being said, I did laugh a few times throughout the movie, with some of the visual gags being quite funny. There is a subplot involving a foreign exchange student character (played by Greta Gerwig) that I found to be distracting. Every time it cut to this character, I was just hoping it would return to the main characters as soon as possible. They are the real heart of the story. I also found some of the editing choices to be awkward, possibly relating to this being stop motion animation and hence, being more difficult to edit. It is possible, but I am by no means an expert in the field. I did overall enjoy the film despite is flaws in the writing, editing and overall simple story. The quality of the animation and the emotional core of the movie kept me engaged throughout the run time of the film and I would definitely like to see this again in theaters with some friends to gauge their reaction to the film. I would recommend the film to Wes Anderson fans, who will probably get the most enjoyment out of the film. The general audience I viewed the film with seemed to enjoy it so I would also give it a recommendation to the wider public as long as you keep an open mind to different styles of film making. Overall Rating: 7/10

reviews.review_title: Got what I expected, Great movie, Great animation, and Dogs.
reviews.content:
Drove an hour to see this one and it was worth it! A bummer it did not have a wide release all at once, but gave us a new chance to experience a different theater. The plot is good and expands a bit more throughout the story past what you know from the trailer - but not to the point of confusion or thorough thought. 
 The animation and characters and scenery were amazing. I already want to watch it again since we had to sit front row so that made it hard to take in all the detail on the big screen being so close.
 I wouldnt bother bringing any kids under 13 or so, as it deserves the PG-13 rating. Some adult talk, a few swears, some blood and depiction of injuries, ect. 
However more important, this isnt a knee-slapping comedy kids movie. It has a good pace and I was never bored, but the pace may be just a bit too slow, and comedy lacking for young kids. However, adults will appreciate this film, especially if you have a thing for stop motion. 
 If you are a feminist or critical of cultural references, maybe dont bother as this movie shows people in their "typical" roles and one of the main heros is an American trying to sway the masses. I hate that I have to mention any of that...just enjoy the great movie!

With in the first few seconds I was already haveing a good time. Wes pulls off another entertaining animation. Each character definitely has there quirks and characteristics. All of wich are enjoyable, even the side characters and villains. Every member of the cast gives a solid performance. It's well paste and structured. Doesn't Direlle off too much in to any small points or subplots no time is wasted on any others stories other then the 3 or so main characters. The core of the story is quite simple, and the situation everyone else is in is well explained. At first I was a little frustrated there wasn't subtitles for the Japanese characters, but soon realized it doesn't matter. We're only given the necessary information. Any additional information could have distracted and/or confused me. The style of animation is pleasing to the eye, with its atension to detail, for even the shortest segments. Additionally the cartoonish style on the televisions add a funny component to the whole film.Stop animation almost always gets extra points in my book. With how much more care and craft, is put in to each and every frame. You can't help but appreciate the film, even with a less then Ideal story.Everything is accompanied by a intense and compelling musical score. That really brings you in to this world.
In short it's a fun and enjoyable film with a gently delivered message that isn't shoved down your throat.Would highly recommend to animation lovers.
Great story, great actors doing the voices, worth watching over and over.
Nice movie for all ages, with a good storyline and a profound message. Also fun to watch.

After The Grand Budapest Hotel, I thought that no film afterwards by the same director would be able to compete, but I was proved wrong when I went to see Anderson's latest movie. The animation style has certainly improved since his first stop motion feature, Fantastic Mr Fox, but Anderson's familiar and much loved directing traits remain. The cinematography is absolutely extraordinary, which is complimented by a range of quirky, funny and well developed characters- despite not being able to understand any of the Japanese characters, it is still easy to empathise and understand the motivations of these characters. The story, though not overly complex, is still intelligent and engaging.
The film may at first appear, especially from the trailers, to be a fun family jaunt in a quirky animation style, but within minutes it is established that relatively mature themes will be explored throughout, which they are, often with explicit detail. This, however, does not harm its availability to younger ages. 
I would thoroughly recommend this film to everyone and hope that none will miss this fantastic film.

Like many of the other reviewers I was hyped to see this film purely because it was a Wes Anderson but I truly had my doubts about how he would pull it off. After leaving the cinema all I can say is WOW... Unlike anything I've ever seen before. There was still so many signature Wes elements but the way the Japanese setting was incorporated was something completely new which just blew me away. Exceptionally witty, heartwarming, and just all round awesome visual experience.

I've never reviewed a movie before! But this film was so delightful that I felt like I should give it a positive review! This has probably become my favorite Wes Anderson film yet. But I'll need to see it a couple more times before I can make that call. The timing in this film is impeccable. The humor has a perfect balance of cute and dark humor it's a weird mix. For a stop motion film it's so meticulous and detailed it's probably the first Stop motion film i've seen where i forgot I was watching a Stop motion film. It's also the perfect length I feel like a lot of stop motion films are short due to budgeting reasons this felt like it told the whole story and left you happy.
A lovely visual story by Wes Anderson accompanied by a brilliant cast with an excellent soundtrack to back it.

This film has art, entertainment, educational and literary values. Through the whole film this idea of conformism is presented through how the Japanese citizens all simply given to the mayors hate for dogs and conform. Other art values include the sound/audio techniques used in the film. Every voice and sound effect lines up perfectly with the kind of animation they used. Entertainment wise it didn't seem to be the most popular film that ever come out in theaters, but it was popular enough. Powerful scenes included whenever the Dog Chief or the main character Atari discovered something new having to do with Atari's dog and Chief's brother Spots. Those scenes seemed to add more excitement and interest in the film. A morale message that can be seen in the film is don't just conform to those in power and their ideas, think for yourself and what you believe is right. Scenes that reinforce this message are whenever Tracy Walker fights for the cause to save the dogs or stands up for what she believes is right. Internal conflict increases well in how Chief has pride in knowing that he must help Atari, but will not until a certain point. External conflict develops in the fight between the main good characters and society. Their will to bring back dogs is against what their society now traditionally believes in. All in all it was a wonderful Wes Anderson movie, some of his best work in my opinion and I think if I had watched this movie as a child I would've loved it even more.

reviews.review_title: Isle of Dogs - handsome, engaging, unique
reviews.content: Bursting full to the brim of mouth watering visuals, stunning production and flawless stop motion animation, Isle of Dogs shines as one of the best animated films ever crafted technically, and possibly the best film by unique and stylised filmmaker Wes Anderson. The film executes an unexpectedly complex story somewhat well, although it doesn't really focus on a main protagonist. Characters like Atari and Koboyashi lack personality, not only due to the language barrier and Anderson's common blank slate characters but also because there is not enough time spent exploring them compared to other supporting roles. I felt if the film was even 10 minutes longer, we could have seen relationships thicken and characters explored more than they were, rather than devoting time to supporting characters who felt more like protagonists as well, thus making the film full of side characters and no focus. Despite this, "Isle of Dogs" still feels special, gorgeous, inspired and heart-warming. The dogs are likable and appealing, and every frame of the film feels as though all the care in the world has been put into it. The astonishing production team has to be commended. Every performance was well done, including the child actors. Although Isle of Dogs features a cute array of animals and a whimsical, childish appearance, it is certainly not a film for young children. With most of the engagement coming from the dialogue driven plot, and an overall dark tone with references to cannibalism, suicide, euthanisation and concentrated genocide - don't take your 7-year-old to this movie but do take your teen to see it. In conclusion, Isle of Dogs is a sweet, aesthetically driven, technical masterpiece which, while lacking in character depth and a consistent tone (like most Anderson flicks), is still a must watch for film lovers and teens and up alike.I would recommend Isle of Dogs.

reviews.review_title: Best film i have seen in a while
reviews.content: I love films, i even like bad ones Unironically, but when you have a film were even cynical assholes think this film is great then you know your doing something right. I was never bored during the film and it was great that there was bearly any scenes were nothing was animated and all scenes contained no effects or cgi, all of it was practical in clever ways. The bad things in this film are very small and not very important but can bring something down. The twist annoyed me but it would have been better if the main dog was spots because it would make out that this character that is tough and violent was a kig caring pet that forgot the luxury days of his life. Overall this was a fantastic film and would recommend to friends and family and people online

reviews.review_title: An improvement on an already solid formula.
reviews.content: Wes Anderson creates meticulously detailed worlds. This is true for all his films, but this one is specifically evident of this fact. Possibly the most "Wes Anderson" film I've ever seen, "Isle of Dogs" is in many ways a spiritual successor to "Fantastic Mr. Fox", the only difference being overall technical quality. "Isle of Dogs" takes the elements from Anderson's previous foray into animation; particularly stilted and short dialogue, whimsical sound design, solid comedic elements, and a vibrant array of color, and improves on every single one. It has enough lighthearted character to make it a genuinely enjoyable theatre-film, but also enough interesting shots and subtext to warrant a second viewing. Though I wouldn't recommend this to someone who doesn't already enjoy Wes Anderson's style, or to anyone under the age of 12 for fear that it would just go over their head... I had a great time watching this film, and would tell everyone else to go see this soon-to-be animated classic immediately.

reviews.review_title: The bark was better than the bite
reviews.content:
A Review of the Movie "Isle of Dogs"
by Banjo the Doberman (translated by Don Kurtz April 2018)(Note from the translator: listening to the original audio tapes of the early drafts of this essay one would only hear various yaps, rarphs, ruff (woof), bow wows et al. Thus the magic of having a human who understands SADB (Standard American Dog Bark)...oh that would be me...to bring this crisp content to non-canine moviegoers...virtually anyone. #sweartogod)Straight away I admit to mixing a cocktail of both regard and rebuke for Isle of Dogs (referred to hereafter as IOD to cool my boiling carpal tunnel).Doesn't that beg the question "What is this movie NOT about?" Decidedly not whale migrations, failed PHD theses, or the lack of a good crème brûlée in Oklahoma. And yet, in spite of the myriad topics not presented, the membrane (synonym for film) is an allegory. We posit good versus evil. Has that clash yet to receive a full treatment in any art or literature? That is question 6 on your homework assignment. So we have a megalomaniac running Megasaki - appropriate. He sends the infected dogs to quarantine on Trash Island. (Bakersfield with a lean shellac of animation.) Imagine conjoining "101 Dalmations" with "Schindler's List". All right don't. But when I think about IOD, mostly during the time I spend spinning in three circles before I lay (laid? lain?) on my Pendleton shirtish bucket by the fire (I know it's July but light it anyway), I face plot holes so substantial and off-white that no matter or radiation can escape. I scraped that from Wikipedia but it somehow works. Or doesn't. You decide. You can stop reading now. Go ahead I dare you. And I will scratch up some dirt on you and yours.Aside: somebody just came up to me, I'd been drowsing, and said "Where's the ball?" Really? So I am supposed to look keen and spirited? You know where the ball is. You pushed it under the couch. :end of aside.Just a few of the miscalculations from Wes Anderson and the other writers:-- How could a band of renegade pups not take a licking? Isn't that what they crave? Unto themselves and each other?
-- How fur can you go with the "Abused Dogs Stage Coup" device? 
-- Notice the cut-rate "Canine Ex Machina" in the trending1 "bucket on a wire" scene. (1Wes bought 1.5 million Twitter followers from Cambridge Analytica.)
-- Think on Rex, King, Duke, Boss, and Chief. Why didn't they flea when presented the opportunity?End of miscalculations.I don't want to kibble on small points but the leash I could do is scratch a hole in the new carpet. (There was something alive under the pad #sweartogod squirrel most likely). 
I discussed this for seven and a half hours with the other dogs on the block that comprise our karass. Our managers were all out "working". Right. So we talked and Gunner said that the one actress put the poo in poodle. Fair? Probably not. Other views held her to be fetching. Bear said that the mayor was so simple he should have been put into a witless protection program. My tenet was empathy for the mentality of the pack. Seeing them eat garbage reminded me of trying to find any watchable shows on DirecTV.Other principles we noted: inside every black dog is a white dog waiting to be shampooed and announced.I lift my leg and give IOD 4 Hydrants and a patch of grass. And I will now accept my chew toy.

reviews.review_title: The best film of 2018 so far
reviews.content:
I am a huge Wes Anderson fan, seeing as he is my favorite director of all time, so buying a ticket for this film was a no-brainer.
The only thing I'm gonna say is: see this right now. It's on Blu-Ray, so no excuses.

The detail that went into this film is just mind-blowing! The sets, script, score, and voice acting are all so perfectly in sync. The film as a whole is just daring enough to be amazing, without overdoing it and taking itself too seriously. Bryan Cranston, Jeff Goldblum, and Courtney B. Vance standout among an all around AMAZING cast. The sets are as aesthetically pleasing as it gets: detailed, colorful, themed, and thought-proving. The plot, as to be expected, is engaging and fun. If you liked Fantastic Mr. Fox, this film was made just for you. Definitely worth your valuable time!

Movies nowadays are very high tech and require a lot of work. An example of this is the recent movie hit Avengers Infinity War, which took so much time just to make a part one as well as took many movie actors hours and hours of practice just to do one scene. Isle of dogs is different in the way that it uses clay figures and use animation to make them move which is a very unique way to film, that many directors just do not do. The thing about this movie is the art of its simplicity, especially in their storyline. The movie is basically all about Japanese people hating dogs because of a corrupt dictator from the cat army who decided to put a disease in a dog which spread fear into the people, giving him power to kick out all dogs. A young boy named Atari is not happy about this, so he decides to leave the country to find his servant dog who was with him during his injury. I love the Visual Design aka Mise en scéne of the movie. The actions are so well timed, the characters are simple yet beautiful,and even the storyline, although somewhat cliché, it doesn't take away the beauty and overall greatness of the movie.Isle of Dogs is unique in the way that even though the language is Japanese, and dubbed to English, there are still parts that are in Japanese. Mr. Anderson was very wise in this decision as those words that are in Japanese hold a very deep meaning that I'm dubbed, could make the viewers not fully grasp the intention of the words used. What it lacks however is that it doesn't fully develop the side characters as when Atari was in trash island, he met a dog and his squad, and after some character development, he gets close with the one dog that doesn't really like him, but after some time and some problems happen, and the other dogs are in danger, and released, their story ends there. The ending doesn't even reveal how they ended up. Basically, what I just stated was merely nitpicking and that didn't really affect my overall perspective on the movie, which is it is great. I actually enjoyed the movie from start to finish and I would definitely recommend other people to watch it if they have the opportunity to.
I don't get the hype.
Amazing premise and visuals, but like in a theme park ride kind of way. A lil bit more research and insight is needed before jumping in and making the cool thing about the cool country.

Isle of Dogs is a visually stunning and creatively unique animated film that is sure to captivate and entertain audiences. The attention to detail in the stop-motion animation is impressive and the voice cast, including Bryan Cranston and Scarlett Johansson, is top-notch. The story is engaging and emotionally resonant, with a perfect balance of humor and heart. While some may find the pacing a bit slow, the film's overall execution is masterful and deserving of its critical acclaim. Overall, I highly recommend Isle of Dogs to anyone looking for a visually stunning and emotionally satisfying cinematic experience.

A very quirky movie with a ton of charm. All of the movie's elements are super well executed, the stop-motion animation, the attention to detail, the language choices, and the acting – it's all very high quality. Wes Anderson's visual style is also very welcome here, the symmetrical shots and the linear camera movements make almost every frame aesthetically pleasing on its own and it makes the whole movie truly beautiful. It's also very funny.
Strange, but it works. Could be a little more slow paced.

An odd film, with it's mixture of the typical Wes Anderson whimsy (seemingly directed at children and amped up to 11 here) while exploring themes perhaps too dark for children.  Setting it in Japan is an interesting if frustrating choice, considering that the canine characters all speak English and the main human character is an American exchange student.  Still, it manages to work on most levels.

When a canine flu impacts the dogs of Megasaki, the iron-fisted Mayor Kobayashi signs a decree banishing all of the dogs to Trash Island in an effort to stop the spread of the disease to humans, leaving a young American exchange student to uncover an insidious conspiracy and save the beloved pets from certain death.  Wes Anderson's Isle of Dogs has everything you love (or hate) about Anderson movies – spectacular and creative visuals, witty dialogue, interesting characters, and, as with his previous animated film Fantastic Mr. Fox, great stop motion animation.  Despite a story that often seems to meander aimlessly, Isle of Dogs has more than enough to offer to offset any shortcomings.  And the dogs are unbearably cute.

Criminally underrated and one of the best stop motions films alongside fantastic mr Fox, Isle of Dogs deserves more praise from critics and audiences alike. Most critical reviews rightly compliment that Beauty Wes Anderson produces. I would say it's his most visually stunning film, beating out all his other visually masterful films which says a lot to how great this movie is crafted. The critics of the film come with the characters and stories themselves:. The consensus seems to be that the story and characters whilst good don't make you connect with them like a Mr Fox or Gustave for example. Though I agree those characters are more relatable and engaging the characters and story here is still no doubt fantastic. There's no real protagonist, we have the pack of dogs Chief being the main leader and the boy who all adventure together to find his old dog spots. The lack of a dead set protagonist is in my opinion not harmful at all. It's true that the rest of the dogs in Chiefs pack are underdeveloped but was there any need to develop them? They are there for comical effect but they needed no either purpose in the narrative. Chief and the boy hold the narrative up incredibly well enough, rounding the story in satisfying character arcs and a great ending. Overall I think isle of dogs story and characters of Chief deserve more respect alongside the beauty the film presents with all the hand crafted sets and characters etc. A criminally unappreciated fantastic movie.
Sonic I think it's so cool to watch

Isle of Dogs tells a striking story about governmental corruption against dogs that is sure to spark interest. The movie evokes strong emotions from the viewers, but feels somewhat monotonous and slow at times, especially during the middle half. The ending portion of the movie is the most intriguing, where most of the action occurred. Overall, because of the beautiful animation and distinctive storyline, I would recommend a watch.

Isle of dogs was as perfect a movie if there ever was one. The voice of the actors and actresses in The Script and the attention to on-screen detail. Perfectly done. A wonderful animation.

Wes Anderson's Isle of Dogs is different. The animation style (of humans) is —to be frank— a little scary and even gross. Like why do humans look like that? It's not bad animation, just different.

It's a pretty sad first act. It pulls you into the story quickly because you wanna know what's going to happen next but it honestly breaks your heart in the process. Trust me when I say that it gets so much better. At certain points in the film you're overcome by emotion, you laugh, you gasp and your eyes widen, and so much more. Definitely worth the watch!

A stacked cast and amazing attention to detail, what more could you ask for in a stop motion film? Andy Gent, Anderson's "right hand man" is a master at his craft. The fur on the dogs and the movement of everything is beautiful. This is probably my favorite stop motion film I've seen because there are just so many amazing moments like when a dog is staring into the ocean and their fur is blowing or when a tv screen shows a computer generated character… it's gorgeous.

It has it's moments of comedy too. There's a few times where I laughed out loud at unexpected jokes which I loved! It's not a full on comedy movie, but the times when they do slide a joke in there is hilarious. Thank you Jason Schwartzman (honestly, he probably didn't write those jokes but I like to believe that he did)

THE BENTO BOX SCENE! This will go down as the most satisfying scene I've ever watched in an animated film. I watched it once, then played it over again, just to see it one more time. So gorgeous.

My one and only critique is that it drags on for just a little too long. There were points that could be sped up and the movie could've ended a lot sooner… towards the end I kept clicking to see how much time was left. Feel good ending though so it was worth the wait! So enjoyable!

Last thing I'll say (reiterate), the look of this film is wonderful. Once you get past the people, that is. Every scene had me saying wow under my breath because it's just so intricate and beautiful. Really enjoyed watching this, probably wouldn't watch it alone again just because it's not something that generally intrigues me but it was good! Only two more Wes films until I've finished his entire filmography!!

i love stop motion and i think if you know someone who doesnt watch it or doesnt like it them show them this cause they will definitly like it. i think the story is quite sad and emotional but its still fun to watch i would love to see a live action remake possibly but im not sure how to feel about using real dogs but possibly.

Out of the two stop motion animation films Wes Anderson has directed, Isle of Dogs takes the cake by a long shot for me, over Fantastic Mr. Fox. The overall tone of the film is more towards an older audience, which I appreciated. 

The stop motion and animation in the film is on par, even superior compared to Fantastic Mr. Fox. It was fun to watch these movies back to back, when they have a decade in between their releases.

"Isle of Dogs" is an incredibly fun, and brilliant film. The sound design was incredibly immersive and beautiful. The character's motives are very one-dimensional, but still feel very 'real' and are easily loved by the audience. The comedy in the film, is fantastic, for both kids and parents. Unlike many films, the comedy relief doesn't really fall flat. It is well thought out and allows for the audience to feel sad when they should, and good when they shouldn't. In addition, Wes Anderson delivers an incredible statement about the victims of a radically extremist ruler, still very relevant in today's time.

One of my favorite movies of all time from the creative story, incredible world building to the flawless stop motion animation, the lighting camera angles and music I can't tell you how much of an experience this movie is!

8/10. Wes Anderson's films are always pretentious, and this one is no exception. That wasn't enough to keep me from enjoying it, though. It was a visual treat - I noted to myself multiple times throughout the film that some frames would look lovely on my wall. There's a picturesque beauty in the grimy garbage heaps and derelict structures that are the backdrops of the film. The voice actors were phenomenal, giving the dogs rich personalities that I like to imagine are how my animals might sound when I'm not around (oh, come on - you do it, too...right?) They are helped by dialogue that is snappy and well written. It's not quite funny enough to me - I like the deadpan sense of humor, but in this case it was in a way that you sort of chuckle and move from on rather than really deeply enjoy, like a series of witty Sunday comic strips tied together. The story is an initially breezy, and later exciting, brand of fun as it follows a young boy who, with the help of a pack of feral dogs, searches for his lost pet. There are welcome hints of noir influence as it deals with the political intrigue surrounding the circumstances of the dogs quarantine from society. Anderson's eccentricity and style can be a bit much as it teeters on the brink of self-indulgence, but this time he pulls it off with the right combination of talent, imagery, and lovable puppers.
The whole movie was amazing. This is a type of movie that we've never seen before. My favorite character in the movie was Chief because I love his personality and his quote “ I Bite ”.

Konnichiwa! Ogenkidesuka! Today is Sunday and that means the London Marathon! The film I'm going to review is the Japanese-American film called the Isle of Dogs. 
The main character is Chief along with his pack and the main antagonist is Mayor Kobayashi but he changes his alignment from bad to good. There is no main antagonist in the film.
It's about a boy (voice of Koyu Rankin) journeys there to rescue his dog Spots (Liev Schreiber), and gets help from a pack of misfit canines who have also been exiled. His quest inspires a group of dog lovers to expose a government conspiracy. 
I recommend the film 5 out of 5 stars because it has good Japanese transliteration and English in it. My father and me really love the film because we are study multiple cultures. I am studying Japanese culture and American culture so I respect both countries. 
Look guys, I am the negotiator, a people person and supporter of both countries. I want these people to get along just so they can be friends.

I'll be honest; I was entirely mesmerized by the animation throughout to the point where I paid little attention to anything else. The stop-motion animation is some of the best I've ever seen with model designs that the designers clearly gave lots of care. The story was a nice complement with its interesting concepts revolving around dogs being frowned upon and had some great characters. Rating: Straight Great

Stunning to look at, fascinating to follow, Isle of Dogs is certainly quirky yet manages to hook us and hold on as this dogs-with-their-boy story unfolds. The use of language is very clever, building awareness of different cultures--not just in the nationalistic sense, but in the values we express in our behaviour. Probably not a family movie for those who revere Lassie, but absolutely one for switched-on teens with and interest in design and (here's the second appearance of this work...) quirkiness.

If I were at a dinner party, but there aren't any more of those, at least for a while, and people were gushing about Wes Anderson movies, I would keep my mouth shut and hope that someone, anyone, would say you either love him or you hate him. If that person went on to bravely say they hate him, I would stand firmly with them and be brave enough at that point to say I hate him too, because everyone seems to love him, and if I was alone in my censure I would be shouted down. I cannot stand him in any way, shape or form. I can watch the first ten seconds of a movie and know it's him. In everything he does his a** is sticking out for all to see. It's all so contrived, so quintessentially Wes Anderson. I was told years ago that when telling a story you should get out of the way. He does the polar opposite in every single second of every scene of every movie he's ever done, and I for one KNOW, for all its great acting, shooting, production, what have you, it's all about Wes Anderson. He will never let the story be itself. Wes Anderson is, "Look at me, look how cool I am, how creative and quirky and funny and amazing I am. Don't you understand? Can't you feel my AMAZINGNESS?!" The dialogue is third rate, what's supposed to be funny isn't, and the cloying, melodramatic narrative is ALL Wes "Big A**" Anderson. I hate it. HATE, just so we're clear. Red flag, don't-marry-someone-if-they-like-Wes-Anderson hate. Now, if you'll excuse me, I think I'll go read a couple pages of Hemingway to clear my palate.

"Isle of Dogs" is my first experience with Wes Anderson's work, and the attention he pours into his craft is undeniable in this film.  The stop-motion animation is simply incredible, the voice cast is fun and the story is charming enough in this unconventional, but very entertaining film.

I  would definitely adhere to the PG-13 rating because there is violence and offensive slang directed towards women but nothing to bad . But if that doesn't bother you I would highly recommend this charming movie.

Wes Anderson at his riskiest on sensitive bases surrounding the handled characterization caused by the disturbingly irrational though ironically satirical nature that will be deemed offensive and horrendous over the narrative treatment. (B+)

It was a very enjoyable watch!  Wes Anderson really managed to find a unique visual style for this.  Everything was beautifully textured, but many times there was a very creepy feel to how some of the scenes were framed in ways that you're taught not to use in photography or film or art lessons.  I think it felt creepy just because the shots were done in ways that just simply aren't done because directors or photographers are taught 'THIS IS WRONG!  NEVER DO THIS!'.  Like having all the subjects facing directly at the viewer shoulder to shoulder close together like you might see in a high school yearbook from 1980 for 'senior chess club'.  I found those creepy feeling scenes to be very compelling though, and they certainly stick out in my mind as the most memorable moments in this beautiful film.

An artistic, enriching masterpiece from the mind of Wes Anderson. Isle of dogs is easily one of the greatest films of all time with its dark tone/atmosphere set with the masterful score and gorgeous imagery.

The animation was cool, the world was quirky, it had a all star cast. But it didn't move me, and is on memorable in the sense that is so weird, not with its impact. It's intricately crafted and executed. The central theme of anti-authoritarianism/fascism is strong and well done. Just less half a star for taking a movie set in Asian culture and making a primary hero in the film a white (exchange?) student.

What is there not to like? It's a message about loving dogs, made by a hilarious and extremely skilled director, stop-motion-animated by some clearly deft animators, and voice-acted by some of the top-billed actors and actresses around. The title is even, phonetically, I Love Dogs! I mean, come on!

Wes Anderson is just showing off his chops at this point and he damn well knows how to properly tell a story. Although she was cute and likable, she never really did or add anything to the movie overall except extra running time. This movie is predictably funny, sweet, quirky, and occasionally a bit harsh in the signature style of Wes Anderson. Its quirkiness will impact audiences differently, but where Darjeeling Limited and The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou had the quirkiness on full display Isle of Dogs relegates it more to the deeper levels of story and narrative structure. 

Closest comparison: It's like The Fantastic Mr. Fox with a more grounded story.

Isle of dogs is an animated stop motion film directed by Wes Anderson. The film is hilarious, adventurous and enjoyable. The films intricate fast-moving plot is well supported by a lush, compelling background score from Alexandre Desplat. Like the screenplay in any Wes Anderson film, the dialogues are hilarious, witty and fast-paced. The fight scenes seem like they have been picked out of from a comic strip so as not to seem too violent, I liked this a lot. Bryan Cranston's voiceover was the standout for me moving from strong and authoritative to soft, caring and lovable. Edward Norton's voiceover was refreshingly funny. The most unprecedented factor in this movie is the exceeding relevance it carries in todays society. The themes range widely from moronic politicians to pollution and its adverse effects. The film subtly hints at the future of the Earth through the vast amount of garbage in the movie and says how that will be our situation soon if we don't take actions. Overall even with the cute dogs and several heartwarming moments, this film will appeal more to adults rather than children.
For me this film was hilarious and a good visual experience with good humour.

Wes Anderson's most recent film, Isle of Dogs, is a wonderful story that is intriguing and different, along with a strong emotional impact. The story follows Atari, the mayor's son, as he escapes home to save his lost dog, Spot. The government has banned all dogs from the city after a deadly strain of snout flu breaks out. The script is mediocre, however, the overall look of the movie more than makes up for it. Since this is an animated movie, Wes Anderson is able to play with a much larger scale than all of his other movies. This is done by making the film more of a science fiction, large scale, action film. As mentioned, the movie is visually spectacular. This movie isn't Wes Anderson's first attempt at an animated feature, Fantastic Mr. Fox was (for lack of a better term) fantastic, and this movie has a very similar quality. The art takes a key element from Japanese culture, which made the movie world very vibrant and exciting. A lot of the voice acting is wonderful, Bill Murray and Edward Norton being stand outs. The language barrier between the dogs and Atari was different from other movies featuring the same kind of language barrier. The dogs have a hard time understanding Atari, ergo allowing us to connect more with the dogs. The dogs themselves are all very unique, and each one ends the perfect way. Though, as I mentioned, the script is only mediocre. The dialogue certainly wasn't the best of Anderson's movies, although dialogue has never been one of his large strengths, though don't get me wrong, I wouldn't call any of the dialogues in his films ‘bad.' I'm not okay with admitting how long it took me to figure out the pun in the name, but it was worth it. In the end, Isle of Dogs is a wonderful, fantastical, animated movie by Wes Anderson. And while the script isn't always the best, nearly every other aspect of it is really enjoyable. It's a very fun watch, and I would highly recommend it. 8.2/10 from me.
Wes Anderson does it again in this animated film. Profound and uniquely humorous. Must watch for all ages.

While both an homage and a bit ethnocentric, Anderson still manages to tell a unique story and develop quirky and humorous characters whose lives draw you in and who you ultimately end up cheering for.
It was alright but I wouldn't watch it again. I just don't liked the dark mood of it.

Wes Anderson does it again. This could be one of the best animated films that came out in 2018.

First off, it's a beautiful film. Hands down. Wes Anderson works his magic and showcases his skill at set-building in every single scene. The choice of stop-motion allows Anderson an insane amount of detail. From individual hairs to random fleas that scurry, no piece of detail gets left out. Each scene is beautiful and stands out on their own. Colors and visuals and media styles mix and blend together to create a beautiful film. The animation is nothing less than captivating.

But the film is more than a delight to the eyes, it's a delight to the ears as well. The music and sounds were perfect. Loved the music throughout. The voice cast was well selected. It's fun guessing which person is playing which character.

The plot was unique and heartwarming. Who can't like a story about a boy and his dog? There are some suspenseful moments, it's a feel-good movie throughout.

I enjoyed the nod to Japanese culture and Anderson's choice of not having subtitles. Though confusing at first, it increases the level of immersion. Double points for accurate Japanese. That's one area most American filmmakers neglect.

I don't think any animated 2018 film could have topped this.

5/5. I loved it. Sorry, cat-lovers.

This movie warmed my heart like no other movie ever has.  Of course I am a lover of dogs and cats (even tho cats do not fare well here) and I have enjoyed all of Wes Anderson's charming movies.  And even tho I am not a big animated movie fan, this is one of the very few movies where I had to go buy the DVD as soon as I saw it.  There is so much detail to discover that I still find something new and enchanting even after all these viewings.

Undeniably creative and fun. More eccentric but more streamlined than Fantastic Mr. Fox; the sort of plot from the getgo that you know will be a wild ride in which the themes and points will emerge. Cleverly and respectfully appropriating Japanese cinema and art makes for a uniquely beautiful film and one that renders the audience in the same camp as the dogs: unable to understand everything except for tone and a few choice words. 
There's something special about hearing these legendary voices behind these hand animated creatures, and Wes Anderson has, in the dogs, created a sort of very refreshingly sweet, honest pack of fun characters for this adventure that intentionally don't fit the stereotypes you would associate with Alphas. 
There's very little not to like about this movie except for the fact that it's very much of little consequence. But I can imagine rewatching this movie many times, sometimes for the visuals and sometimes for the pitch perfect acting/dialogue/animation.
Great looking animation, this is the best exemple of the director's style, but looses a bit with some culturaly insensitive points.

The voice actors were phenomenal, giving the dogs rich personalities that I like to imagine are how my animals might sound when I'm not around (oh, come on - you do it, too...right?) They are helped by dialogue that is snappy and well written. It's not quite funny enough to me - I like the deadpan sense of humor, but in this case it was in a way that you sort of chuckle and move from on rather than really deeply enjoy, like a series of witty Sunday comic strips tied together. Brilliant! I love the on-the-nose humor, the cinematography and the overwhelming respect for audience intelligence. This movie inspired in me a new curiosity for Japanese culture while also providing a truly original story. 5 stars: couldn't be better!

Isle Of Dogs, along with another stop-motion Missing Link, are tied for my favourite animated films. Isle Of Dogs is very different, however; it is so quirky and whimsical (like all of Wes Anderson's charming films) it's impossible to forget.

The best animated movie I have ever watched. Incredibly creative, witty, moving, and captivating. Very unique and well made.

This movie was delightful! It had an original story, good performances, and some of the best-crafted stop-motion animation that I've ever seen! Seriously, this movie is beautiful! The movement is so smooth and it's so detailed! It's a feast for the eyes! Now, the movie is a little slow in a few places, but I still think this is a great film overall. Just don't show it to your kids, it isn't a kids movie. Just because it's animated doesn't mean it's for kids. It isn't even that inappropriate, I just don't think kids would be very interested in what's going on. Show them Fantastic Mr. Fox instead, the other stop-motion animated film by director Wes Anderson. I think I like that one a little better, but I still highly recommend both! Watch them on Blu-Ray if you can.

This film is godly. The stop motion is mind blowing, the script is amazing, the story is simple on the surface but gets deeper as the movie progresses, the shots are awesome, the score is incredible, the characters are loveable, and its so so so funny! Wes Anderson has done it again!

The care and effort put into this movie's animation and voice acting is astonishing. As a movie, it has its flaws and feels a little slow at parts, but that hardly really affects my score because this movie's slowest moments are over quick and it puts you right back into the moment. Another thing worth mentioning is the cast which fits this movie like a glove. This is a must-see for anyone striving for creativity in an uninspired era of films. A true breath of fresh air into the lungs of film media
Bizzarre but also visually fresh and compelling, it has its flows but overall it gets the job done.

The backdrop / pastiche use of Japanese cultural items, in a jumbled fashion, by a white filmmaker bugged me. I wonder if I would have liked it better set in, say, LA, with stop motion aesthetics to match.

Incredibly disappointing, Isle of Dogs is a bizarre mess of a film from writer/director Wes Anderson.  When a strange disease infects the dog population Megasaki City expels them to Trash Island, leading the mayor's 12-year old ward Atari Kobayashi to go there in search of his beloved dog.  Featuring the voice talents of Bryan Cranston, Edward Norton, Liev Schreiber, Bill Murray, and Scarlett Johansson, the cast is quite impressive (as are those of most Anderson films).  But the story is really dumb, and told poorly.  For some reason the film is set in a weird dystopic Japan, and there's no subtitles for the Japanese dialog.  Also, the stop-motion animation doesn't seem to add anything to the film (other than to heighten its strangeness).  However, Anderson's trademark comedy comes through and delivers some good laughs.  While Isle of Dogs doesn't work, it's an interesting failure.
A good story with amazing visuals. Some parts drag on a bit too long.

But I almost never laugh.  But it's not horrible either. It's not like someone who's painfully unfunny, it's just . . . whatever. He manages to pull together some good casts, I'll say that. Lots of well-respected white people work with Wes Anderson.   So Isle of Dogs is an animated thing and I have to say: I like it better than most of his other stuff. On deeper thought, yes, it is my favorite Wes Anderson movie.  It's okay.  6.8 out of 10

Finally got this one and I gotta say this is another solid Wes Anderson film. Much like his previous stop motion animated film Fantastic Mr. Fox (2009) Isle of Dogs is a very charming story with some really great voice acting. Set in the near future in Japan Isle of Dogs tells the tale of a Japan that has been overrun by a canine influenza that has affected all the dogs on the island. Mayor Kobayashi (Kunichi Nomura) signs a bill that sends ll the dogs to Trash Island to keep them isolated from humans. Six months go by and a young boy named Atari (Koyu Rankin) crash lands onto Trash Island looking for his dog Spots (Liev Schreiber). He befriends some stray dogs on the island named Chief (Bryan Cranston), Rex (Edward Norton), King (Bob Balaban), Duke (Jeff Goldblum) & Boss (Bill Murray). Together they guide Atari through the island searching for Spots and along the way discovering a conspiracy about what's really going on. The film looks great. The use of the stop motion here is perfect and gives it a very distinct style. In a very Wes Anderson kind of way the film blends story, music and cinematography to give it the vibe you may be familiar with if you're a fan of Anderson's films. The film has a lot of little quirky moments and although I wouldn't say this is better than Fantastic Mr. Fox I did find it very close to that one and enjoyed it. Plus come on it's a movie about dogs that talk and have a witty sense of humor what's not to like. This is a solid film that I really enjoyed and would recommend checking out!

Just terrible.

I admit that I am predisposed to love this movie.  It's all there in the name - if you haven't caught it, the title is a homonym of sorts for "I Love Dogs"... and indeed, I do love dogs!  Now, you don't have to love dogs to love this movie... but even if you don't, I'll bet you that by the end of this movie, you'll love them a little more.  It is just delightful.   This is a Wes Anderson film, so you know even before it starts that it's going to be chock full of charm, whimsy, and symmetry, and it does not disappoint on any of those counts.  Anderson is one of the most original and innovative filmmakers working today; he has become a master of the medium and uses it in ways that no one else does, creating films that are always uniquely his.  Though this is an animated film, it's a pretty adult movie with mature themes - I would say it's probably not the best choice for small kids, but it's great for older ones.  The whole film is an allegory for xenophobia and the disenfranchisement of marginalized populations (the film is ostensibly set in bizarro-world Japan, but I would argue that the attitudes of the people in this film are more similar to American culture right now).  That's a lot going on for an animated film, but its genius is that it's also really funny, sweet, and surprisingly sentimental.  This is a film that brilliantly toes the line between darkness and lightness, illustrating serious themes with humorous execution.  For some reason, the way the characters all look straight into the camera creates such a comedic effect.  The reaction shots alone are priceless... and those little dog-sneezes!  Adorable!   The ending is a little contrived, but whatever, I wanted the happy ending and was willing to sacrifice realism to get it.  This is definitely my favorite movie of 2018 (so far), it is such a joy.  He is a smart and clever man, that Wes Anderson, and he has made a smart and clever movie that is massively appealing while also delivering a potent message.  Standing O.

The simplicity of the story adds to the enjoyment of Wes Anderson's quirky style. I believe that this and Fantastic Mr. Fox are among his best works. What starts of as wry ends up being genuinely funny, while simultaneously heartwarming, not an easy feat to achieve.

I honestly didn't like this movie. Too many captions, too many subtitles, too many stories to keep track of and too many creepy, soul crushing stares into the camera. Although this movie felt a bit long-winded near the end, the beautifully crafted visual art and Wes Anderson pacing kept me interested throughout. I found myself getting surprised at how emotional some scenes made me. However, I suppose dogs are an easy subject to get attached too. Lastly, the finale was a perfectly satisfying way to end this grand story, in my opinion.

Isle of Dogs is More Than Tricks
Wes Anderson is a divisive director and Isle of Dogs is a divisive movie. Some critics say it holds up, some critics say it's too much, and everyone has an opinion on where it fits in the Anderson canon. As a Wes Anderson novice, here's my take; Isle of Dogs charms, pleases, and keeps you on the edge of your seat, often squinting at the excruciating detail. It's a thought provoking tale of childishness, exile, and most importantly, dogs, 
It is with incredible speed that Isle of Dogs diagrams itself out. A quick narrator (who is, of course, a dog) and explanatory inter-shot text cards waste no time setting the scene. The Kobayashi Dynasty, a vicious cat loving empire set on the annihilation of dog-kind, reigns over a feudal Japan. Dogs are on the cusp of extinction. Suddenly, a boy samurai appears, beheads the leader of the Kobayashi, and recites his haiku,
"I turn my back.
On Mankind!
Frost on windowpane."
The audience is given a moment to think about this. Then, a rapid cut reveals kids in a school auditorium, purposefully drumming. These kids serve as the score for much of film, to great effect until you start noticing it (If you haven't watched it yet, sorry!) but here, they stop. We're shown Megasaki, a wonderfully detailed city in a near-future Japan. Haunting singing and slow pans of empty streets build tension. Everyone's in the town hall. Mayor Kobayashi (we're told by an interpreter, only barking is translated.) unveils a decree; because of the rampant dog flu and overpopulation, all dogs in Megasaki will be banished to Trash Island, the Isle of Dogs. Professor Watanabe, desperately appeals to the crowd. He's nearly found a cure for the Dog Flu. After a somber "Whatever happened to 'man's best friend?" he's booed down. The audience calls for immediate ratification of the decree, and Spots, Kobayashi's dog, is wheeled out in a locked cage to be deported.
Six months pass. Atari Kobayashi, distant nephew and adopted ward to the Mayoral Household, has stolen a prop plane to go find Spots. He crashes and meets Rex, Duke, King, Boss and Chief. Four pets and a curmudgeonly stray, in that order. They're a rag-tag crew just trying to survive in their new harsh landscape. Atari doggedly gets up from the crash site, snaps off a piece of metal lodged in his head, the holds out a photo of Spots for the dogs to see. He's come prepared for the coming journey.
These opening shots are (from what I know) classic Anderson; sheer, diagraming angles, camera facing characters, rapid cuts; the cinematography in this film is Anderson untethered, and it comes out at crane-neck speeds. The first time through, I felt dragged; I was a toddler walking a mastiff. Gags and goofy lines like "beheaded the head of the head of the Kobayashi clan," kept me from being left in the stop-motion cotton ball dust, but I kept a far better pace the second time through. The atmosphere these shots provide is a perfect launchpad for most of the rest of the film, but a too-long ending sees that plane set a little too soon. Isle of Dogs is best when this momentum is present.
Isle of Dogs splays out some harsh realities of the world, starting with scheming, political corruption, and abandoning sick dogs to die on an island made out of trash. However, another point of view shows an Isle of Dogs about cat-lovers fighting dog-lovers with evil robot dogs and wasabi poison. It's childish, and that really makes the film. Even the animation contributes; it's a cartoon! Complete with explosions and dustball brawls. Just look at the title. These two faces play brilliant foils for one another, which becomes clearer and clearer as the film goes on. Atari risks everything to save the last friend he has. Mayor Kobayashi hates dogs because he's with the cats and cats must hate dogs. Atari hijacks an airplane to go visit an island full of dogs. Mayor Kobayashi struggles with the burden of following his family's way. All of the human plot-movers in Isle of Dogs are children acting like adults or adults acting like children.
The human cast of this movie may have a lot going on, but this movie stands on more that two legs. This movie is also about dogs, and in this case, outcasts. Many of the Isle's dogs lead lives  very human lives back on the mainland; they were mascots, actors, bodyguards, and show dogs. Chief, our main pooch played by Bryan Cranston, was a stray. Before Atari's arrival and the subsequent adventure, a brief glimpse shows how life happens on the Isle of Dogs. Roving packs fight for every meal. It's dog-eat-dog anarchy. However, the pack we follow has built within itself an order. They're a democracy. There's no leader; they're all leaders. They vote one way while Chief disagrees and begrudgingly follows. When they all decide to help the little pilot, Chief growls and stands off. "I bite." he says when Atari tries to pet him. It might seem like being shipped off to a trash island might be an equalizer for the dogs, perhaps with the survival-savvy strays coming out on top, Chief is still in some ways the outcast of the party. Deep down, he does want to help Atari find his dog; in the same way, he wants to find a home too, however reluctant he is to admit it. So, when in the middle of another vote a trolley unexpectedly splits leaving Chief with Atari, it's one of the most interesting points of character development in the film. Chief has lost his pack, the only home he's ever known up until that point, and he's stuck with this kid who want him to act like his pet, which goes against everything he stands for. Eventually though, Chief finds his home through Atari. They play fetch. Atari gives Chief a comically effective bath. When they finally regroup with the rest of the pack for the main adventure to resume, we have a much better understanding of both Chief and Atari.
Wes Anderson's Isle of Dogs meticulous scrolls through a thousand beautiful dioramas. The stop-motion is immersive and the characters are full of life. Expect droll humor, novel shots, and visual gags. Under the surface? It's got themes and motifs worth gnawing on for a while. Isle of Dogs is solid. It's a little too long, but otherwise amazing.

(Note: All credit of this movie review is due to Ulysses S Hale.)
